text: Yahweh spoke to Moses in the tent of meeting in the Desert of Sinai. It was the first day of the second month in the second year after leaving Egypt. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Take a census of the whole community of Israel by families and households. List every man by name
speaker: Narrator

text: who is at least 20 years old. You and Aaron must register everyone in Israel who is eligible for military duty. List them by divisions.
speaker: Narrator

text: One man from each tribe will help you. Each of these men must be the head of a household.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Here are the names of the men who will help you:
Elizur, son of Shedeur, from the tribe of Reuben;
speaker: Narrator

text: Shelumiel, son of Zurishaddai, from the tribe of Simeon;
speaker: Narrator

text: Nahshon, son of Amminadab, from the tribe of Judah;
speaker: Narrator

text: Nethanel, son of Zuar, from the tribe of Issachar;
speaker: Narrator

text: Eliab, son of Helon, from the tribe of Zebulun;
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: Abidan, son of Gideoni, from the tribe of Benjamin;
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahiezer, son of Ammishaddai, from the tribe of Dan;
speaker: Narrator

text: Pagiel, son of Ochran, from the tribe of Asher;
speaker: Narrator

text: Eliasaph, son of Deuel, from the tribe of Gad;
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahira, son of Enan, from the tribe of Naphtali.”
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the men chosen from the community, the leaders of their ancestors’ tribes, and heads of the divisions of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses and Aaron took the men who had been named
speaker: Narrator

text: and assembled the whole community on the first day of the second month. Each man at least 20 years old provided his genealogy by family and household. Then his name was listed.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses registered the men of Israel in the Desert of Sinai as Yahweh had commanded him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The roster of families and households for the descendants of Reuben, Israel’s firstborn son, listed every man by name who was at least 20 years old and eligible for military duty.
speaker: Narrator

text: The total for the tribe of Reuben was 46,500.
speaker: Narrator

text: The roster of families and households for the descendants of Simeon registered and listed every man by name who was at least 20 years old and eligible for military duty.
speaker: Narrator

text: The total for the tribe of Simeon was 59,300.
speaker: Narrator

text: The roster of families and households for the descendants of Gad listed the men by name who were at least 20 years old and eligible for military duty.
speaker: Narrator

text: The total for the tribe of Gad was 45,650.
speaker: Narrator

text: The roster of families and households for the descendants of Judah listed the men by name who were at least 20 years old and eligible for military duty.
speaker: Narrator

text: The total for the tribe of Judah was 74,600.
speaker: Narrator

text: The roster of families and households for the descendants of Issachar listed the men by name who were at least 20 years old and eligible for military duty.
speaker: Narrator

text: The total for the tribe of Issachar was 54,400.
speaker: Narrator

text: The roster of families and households for the descendants of Zebulun listed the men by name who were at least 20 years old and eligible for military duty.
speaker: Narrator

text: The total for the tribe of Zebulun was 57,400.
speaker: Narrator

text: The roster of families and households for the descendants of Joseph—those from Ephraim—listed the men by name who were at least 20 years old and eligible for military duty.
speaker: Narrator

text: The total for the tribe of Ephraim was 40,500.
speaker: Narrator

text: The roster of families and households for the descendants of Manasseh listed the men by name who were at least 20 years old and eligible for military duty.
speaker: Narrator

text: The total for the tribe of Manasseh was 32,200.
speaker: Narrator

text: The roster of families and households for the descendants of Benjamin listed the men by name who were at least 20 years old and eligible for military duty.
speaker: Narrator

text: The total for the tribe of Benjamin was 35,400.
speaker: Narrator

text: The roster of families and households for the descendants of Dan listed the men by name who were at least 20 years old and eligible for military duty.
speaker: Narrator

text: The total for the tribe of Dan was 62,700.
speaker: Narrator

text: The roster of families and households for the descendants of Asher listed the men by name who were at least 20 years old and eligible for military duty.
speaker: Narrator

text: The total for the tribe of Asher was 41,500.
speaker: Narrator

text: The roster of families and households for the descendants of Naphtali listed the men by name who were at least 20 years old and eligible for military duty.
speaker: Narrator

text: The total for the tribe of Naphtali was 53,400.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses, Aaron, and the 12 leaders of Israel, each representing his own family, added up these totals.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Israelites were registered by households. The grand total of men who were at least 20 years old and eligible for military duty
speaker: Narrator

text: But the households from the tribe of Levi were not registered along with the other Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh had said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Don’t register the tribe of Levi or include them in the census with the other Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Put the Levites in charge of the tent of God’s words, including the equipment for the tent and everything else having to do with the tent. The Levites will carry the tent and all its equipment. They will take care of the tent and camp around it.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the tent has to be moved, the Levites will take it down. When we camp, they will set it up. Anyone else who comes near the tent will be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The other Israelites will camp with each family in its own area under its own flag.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Levites will camp all around the tent of God’s words. In this way the Lord won’t be angry with the community of Israel. So the Levites will be in charge of the tent of God’s words.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites did everything as Yahweh commanded Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh spoke to Moses and Aaron,
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Israelites will put up their tents with each family under the flag that symbolizes its household. They will put their tents around the tent of meeting, facing it.
speaker: Narrator

text: “On the east side, facing the rising sun, the armies led by Judah will camp under their flag. The leader for the people of Judah is Nahshon, son of Amminadab.
speaker: Narrator

text: The total number of men in his army is 74,600.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Next to them will be the tribe of Issachar. The leader for the people of Issachar is Nethanel, son of Zuar.
speaker: Narrator

text: The total number of men in his army is 54,400.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then will be the tribe of Zebulun. The leader for the people of Zebulun is Eliab, son of Helon.
speaker: Narrator

text: The total number of men in his army is 57,400.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The grand total of all the troops in Judah’s camp is 186,400. They will be the first group to move out.
speaker: Narrator

text: “On the south side the armies led by Reuben will camp under their flag. The leader for the people of Reuben is Elizur, son of Shedeur.
speaker: Narrator

text: The total number of men in his army is 46,500.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Next to them will be the tribe of Simeon. The leader for the people of Simeon is Shelumiel, son of Zurishaddai.
speaker: Narrator

text: The total number of men in his army is 59,300.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then will be the tribe of Gad. The leader for the people of Gad is Eliasaph, son of Deuel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The total number of men in his army is 45,650.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The grand total of all the troops in Reuben’s camp is 151,450. They will be the second group to move out.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When the tent of meeting is moved, the Levites will stay in the middle of the groups. The tribes will move out in the same order as they are in the camp, everyone in place under his own flag.
speaker: Narrator

text: “On the west side the armies led by Ephraim will camp under their flag. The leader for the people of Ephraim is Elishama, son of Ammihud.
speaker: Narrator

text: The total number of men in his army is 40,500.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Next to them will be the tribe of Manasseh. The leader for the people of Manasseh is Gamaliel, son of Pedahzur.
speaker: Narrator

text: The total number of men in his army is 32,200.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then will be the tribe of Benjamin. The leader for the people of Benjamin is Abidan, son of Gideoni.
speaker: Narrator

text: The total number of men in his army is 35,400.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The grand total of all the troops in Ephraim’s camp is 108,100. They will be the third group to move out.
speaker: Narrator

text: “On the north side the armies led by Dan will camp under their flag. The leader for the people of Dan is Ahiezer, son of Ammishaddai.
speaker: Narrator

text: The total number of men in his army is 62,700.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Next to them will be the tribe of Asher. The leader for the people of Asher is Pagiel, son of Ochran.
speaker: Narrator

text: The total number of men in his army is 41,500.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then will be the tribe of Naphtali. The leader for the people of Naphtali is Ahira, son of Enan.
speaker: Narrator

text: The total number of men in his army is 53,400.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The grand total of all the men in Dan’s camp is 157,600. They will be the last group to move out. They will travel under their own flag.”
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the total number of Israelites, counted by households. The grand total of all the troops in the camps was 603,550.
speaker: Narrator

text: As Yahweh had commanded Moses, the Levites were not registered along with the other Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Israelites did everything as Yahweh had commanded Moses. They set up camp under their flags, and each person traveled with his own family and household.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the list of Aaron and Moses’ descendants at the time when Yahweh spoke to Moses on Mount Sinai.
speaker: Narrator

text: The names of Aaron’s sons are Nadab (the firstborn), Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the names of Aaron’s sons, the anointed priests, who were ordained to serve as priests.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nadab and Abihu died in Yahweh’s presence because they offered unauthorized fire in Yahweh’s presence in the Desert of Sinai. They had no children. So only Eleazar and Ithamar served as priests during the lifetime of their father Aaron.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Bring the tribe of Levi, and have them stand in front of the priest Aaron to assist him.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will work for him and the whole community in front of the tent of meeting, doing what needs to be done for the inner tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will take care of all the furnishings in the tent of meeting and work for the Israelites, doing what needs to be done for the inner tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give the Levites to Aaron and his sons. The Levites will be the only Israelites given to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Appoint Aaron and his sons to serve as priests. Anyone else who tries to do the priests’ duties must be put to death.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Out of all the Israelites, I have taken the Levites to be substitutes for every firstborn male offspring among them. The Levites are mine,
speaker: Narrator

text: because every firstborn is mine. The day I killed every firstborn male in Egypt, I set apart as holy every firstborn in Israel, whether human or animal. They will be mine. I am Yahweh.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh said to Moses in the Desert of Sinai,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Count the Levites by households and families. Count every male who is at least one month old.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses did what Yahweh said and registered them as he had been commanded.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gershon, Kohath, and Merari were the sons of Levi.
speaker: Narrator

text: Libni and Shimei were the sons of Gershon. Their families were named after them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel were the sons of Kohath. Their families were named after them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Mahli and Mushi were the sons of Merari. Their families were named after them.
These were the households of Levite families.
speaker: Narrator

text: To Gershon belonged the families descended from Libni and Shimei. These were the families descended from Gershon.
speaker: Narrator

text: The total number of all the males at least one month old was 7,500.
speaker: Narrator

text: The families descended from Gershon put up their tents on the west side behind the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: The leader of the Gershonite households was Eliasaph, son of Lael.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the tent of meeting the Gershonites were in charge of the inner tent, the outer tent and cover, the screen for the entrance to the tent of meeting,
speaker: Narrator

text: the curtains for the courtyard, the screen for the entrance to the courtyard that surrounds the inner tent and the altar, and the ropes. They took care of all these things.
speaker: Narrator

text: To Kohath belonged the families descended from Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel. These were the families descended from Kohath.
speaker: Narrator

text: The number of all the males at least one month old was 8,600. They were in charge of the holy place.
speaker: Narrator

text: The families descended from Kohath put up their tents on the south side of the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: The leader of the Kohathite families and households was Elizaphan, son of Uzziel.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were in charge of the ark, the table, the lamp stand, the altars, the utensils used in the holy place, and the screen. They took care of all these things.
speaker: Narrator

text: The chief leader of the Levites was Eleazar, son of the priest Aaron. It was Eleazar’s duty to supervise those who were in charge of the holy place.
speaker: Narrator

text: To Merari belonged the families descended from Mahli and Mushi. These were the families descended from Merari.
speaker: Narrator

text: The total number of all the males at least one month old was 6,200.
speaker: Narrator

text: The leader of the Merarite families and households was Zuriel, son of Abihail. They put up their tents on the north side of the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was the duty of the Merarites to be in charge of the framework of the inner tent, the crossbars, posts, sockets, and all the equipment. They took care of all these things.
speaker: Narrator

text: They also took care of the posts for the surrounding courtyard, the bases, pegs, and ropes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses, Aaron, and his sons put up their tents on the east side in front of the tent of meeting. They were in charge of the holy place on behalf of the Israelites. Anyone else who tried to do the Levites’ duties had to be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: The grand total of Levites that Moses and Aaron counted at Yahweh’s command, by families, every male who was at least one month old, was 22,000.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh said to Moses, “Register every firstborn male of the Israelites who is at least one month old, and make a list of their names.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am Yahweh. Take the Levites for me to be substitutes for all firstborn Israelites. Also take the animals of the Levites to be substitutes for all firstborn animals of the Israelites.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses registered all the firstborn Israelites as Yahweh commanded him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The total of all the firstborn males at least one month old was 22,273. They were listed by name.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Take the Levites to be substitutes for all the firstborn Israelites and the animals of the Levites to be substitutes for their animals. The Levites will be mine. I am Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: There are 273 more firstborn male Israelites than there are Levites.
speaker: Narrator

text: It will cost you two ounces of silver per person (using the standard weight of the holy place) to buy them back.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give the silver to Aaron and his sons. It will buy back those Israelites who outnumber the Levites.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses took this ransom money from the Israelites who outnumbered the Levites.
speaker: Narrator

text: The silver Moses collected for the firstborn Israelites weighed 34 pounds, using the standard weight of the holy place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses did what Yahweh said and gave Aaron and his sons this ransom money as he had been commanded.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh said to Moses and Aaron,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Take a census of the Levites who are descended from Kohath. List them by families and households.
speaker: Narrator

text: Register all the men between the ages of 30 and 50 who are qualified to work at the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is the work the Kohathites will do in the tent of meeting: They will take care of the most holy things.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the camp is supposed to move, Aaron and his sons will go in and take down the canopy that hangs over the ark containing the words of God’s promise. First they will cover the ark with the canopy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Over this they will put a covering of fine leather. On top of that they will spread a cloth made entirely of violet material. Then they will put the poles in place.
speaker: Narrator

text: “They will spread a violet cloth over the table of the presence and put on it the plates, dishes, bowls, and pitchers for the wine offerings. The bread that is always in the Lord’s presence will also be on it.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will spread a bright red cloth over everything on the table. They will cover all this with fine leather. Then they will put the poles in place.
speaker: Narrator

text: “They will take a violet cloth and cover the lamp stand, as well as the lamps, tongs, trays, and all the containers for the olive oil used in the lamps.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they will put the lamp stand and all its utensils under a covering of fine leather and put them on a frame to carry them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “They will spread a violet cloth over the gold altar and cover the cloth with fine leather. Then they will put the poles in place.
speaker: Narrator

text: “They will take all the articles that are used in the holy place, put them in a violet cloth, cover that with fine leather, and put them on a frame to carry them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “After they take the ashes away, they will spread a purple cloth over the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Next, they will put all the accessories used at the altar on it. These are the trays, forks, shovels, and bowls—all the altar’s accessories. They will spread a covering of fine leather over all this. Then they will put the poles in place.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When Aaron and his sons have finished covering the holy things and the camp is ready to move, the Kohathites will come to carry all the holy articles. They must never touch the holy things, or they will die. The Kohathites will carry all the things from the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Eleazar, son of the priest Aaron, will be in charge of the oil for the lamps, the sweet-smelling incense, the daily grain offering, and the anointing oil. He is in charge of the whole tent and everything in it, the holy place and its contents.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh said to Moses and Aaron,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Don’t let the Kohathite families from Levi’s tribe be destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what you must do so that they won’t die when they come near the most holy things: Aaron and his sons will go into the holy place and tell each man what he will do and what he will carry.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Kohathites must not go in to look at the holy things, even for a moment, or they will die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Also take a census of the Gershonites. List them by households and families.
speaker: Narrator

text: Register all the men between the ages of 30 and 50 who are qualified to serve at the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what the Gershonite families will do and what they will carry:
speaker: Narrator

text: They will carry the sheets that are part of the inner tent and the tent of meeting. They will also carry the inner cover for the tent of meeting, the outer cover of fine leather that goes over it, the screen for the entrance to the tent of meeting,
speaker: Narrator

text: the curtains for the courtyard around the tent and the altar, the screen for the entrance to the courtyard, the ropes, and all the equipment used to set up the curtains. The Gershonites will do everything that needs to be done with these things.
speaker: Narrator

text: All their work, whatever they carry and all their duties, will be done under the direction of Aaron and his sons. You are in charge of telling them everything they’re supposed to carry.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the work of the Gershonite families in the tent of meeting. Ithamar, son of the priest Aaron, will be in charge of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Register the Merarites by families and households.
speaker: Narrator

text: Register all the men between the ages of 30 and 50 who are qualified to serve at the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are their duties as they work at the tent of meeting: They will carry the framework for the inner tent, the crossbars, posts, and sockets,
speaker: Narrator

text: the posts for the surrounding courtyard, the bases, pegs, and ropes. They must take care of all this equipment. Tell each man by name the things he will carry.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Merarite families will do as they work at the tent of meeting. Ithamar, son of the priest Aaron, will be in charge of them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses, Aaron, and the leaders of the community registered the Kohathites by their families and households.
speaker: Narrator

text: They registered all the men between the ages of 30 and 50 who were qualified to work at the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: The total of those who were registered was 2,750. They were listed by families.
speaker: Narrator

text: This was the total of all those in the Kohathite families who served at the tent of meeting. Moses and Aaron did as Yahweh had commanded Moses and registered the Kohathites.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Gershonites were registered by families and households.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the men between the ages of 30 and 50 who were qualified to serve at the tent of meeting were registered.
speaker: Narrator

text: The total of those who were registered was 2,630. They were listed by families and households.
speaker: Narrator

text: This was the total of all those in the Gershonite families who worked at the tent of meeting. Moses and Aaron did as Yahweh had commanded Moses and registered the Gershonites.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Merarites were registered by families and households.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the men between the ages of 30 and 50 who were qualified to serve at the tent of meeting were registered.
speaker: Narrator

text: The total of all those who were registered was 3,200. They were listed by families.
speaker: Narrator

text: This was the total of those registered in the Merarite families. Moses and Aaron did as Yahweh had commanded Moses and registered the Merarites.
speaker: Narrator

text: The grand total of all the Levites whom Moses, Aaron, and the leaders of Israel registered was 8,580. They were listed by families and households.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the men between the ages of 30 and 50 who were qualified to do the work of serving and who carried the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text:
At Yahweh’s command through Moses each man was registered and told what to do and what to carry.
So they were registered as Yahweh commanded Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Command the Israelites to send outside the camp anyone who has a serious skin disease or a discharge or anyone who is unclean from touching a dead body.
speaker: Narrator

text: Send all of these unclean men and women outside the camp. They must not make this camp where I live among you unclean.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Israelites did as Yahweh had told Moses. They sent these unclean people outside the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell the Israelites: If you do something wrong to another person, you have been unfaithful to Yahweh. When you realize your guilt,
speaker: Narrator

text: you must confess your sin, pay in full for what you did wrong, add one-fifth to it, and give it to the person who was wronged.
speaker: Narrator

text: But there may be no heir to whom the payment can be made. In that case, the payment for what you did wrong must be given to Yahweh for the priest to use. This payment is in addition to the ram which makes peace with the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Any contribution over and above the holy offerings that the Israelites bring to the priest will belong to the priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each person’s holy offerings will belong to that person, but whatever is given to the priest will belong to the priest.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh said to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Speak to the Israelites and tell them: A man’s wife may have been unfaithful to him
speaker: Narrator

text: and may have had sexual intercourse with another man without her husband’s knowledge. She may have kept it secret if there were no witnesses to accuse her and she wasn’t caught in the act.
speaker: Narrator

text: “A husband may have a fit of jealousy and suspect his wife, whether she was actually unfaithful or not.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must then take his wife to the priest along with eight cups of barley flour as an offering for her. He must not pour olive oil on the flour or put frankincense on it, since it is a grain offering brought because of the husband’s jealousy, an offering used for a confession—to remind someone of a sin that was committed.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The priest will have the woman come forward and stand in Yahweh’s presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the priest will take holy water in a piece of pottery and put some dust from the floor of the tent into the water.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest will bring the woman into Yahweh’s presence and loosen her hair. In her hands he will put the offering used for a confession (that is, the grain offering brought because of the husband’s jealousy). The priest will hold in his hands the bitter water that can bring a curse.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then the priest will say to her, ‘If no other man has had sexual intercourse with you and you haven’t been unfaithful to your husband, you’re not guilty. This bitter water that can bring a curse will not harm you.
speaker: Narrator

text: If, in fact, you have been unfaithful and have had sexual intercourse with another man,
speaker: Narrator

text:
may Yahweh make you an example for your people to see what happens when the curse of this oath comes true: Yahweh will make your uterus drop and your stomach swell.’
“Then the priest will administer the oath and the curse by saying:
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘May this water that can bring a curse go into your body and make your stomach swell and your uterus drop!’
“Then the woman will say, ‘Amen, amen!’
speaker: Narrator

text: “The priest will write these curses on a scroll and wash them off into the bitter water.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he will have the woman drink the bitter water that can bring the curse. This water will go into her and become bitter.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest will take the grain offering she was holding, present it to Yahweh, and bring it to the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest will take a handful of the grain offering as a memorial portion and burn it on the altar. Then he will have the woman drink the water.
speaker: Narrator

text: If she has become unclean by being unfaithful to her husband, the water that can bring the curse will go into her and become bitter. Her stomach will swell, her uterus will drop, and she will become cursed among her people.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if the woman is not unclean and is pure, she is not guilty and will be able to have children.
speaker: Narrator

text: “These are the instructions for how to deal with jealousy. They tell you what to do when a woman is unfaithful to her husband and becomes unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: They also tell you what to do when a husband has a fit of jealousy and is suspicious of his wife. He will make his wife stand in Yahweh’s presence, and the priest will do everything these instructions tell him to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: The husband isn’t guilty of doing anything wrong, but the woman will suffer the consequences of her sin.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Speak to the Israelites and tell them: A man or a woman may make a special vow to live as a Nazirite dedicated to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nazirites must never drink wine, liquor, vinegar made from wine or liquor, or any kind of grape juice, and they must never eat fresh grapes or raisins.
speaker: Narrator

text: As long as they are Nazirites, they must never eat anything that comes from a grapevine, not even grape seeds or skins.
speaker: Narrator

text: “As long as they are under the Nazirite vow, no razor may touch their heads. During the entire time that they are dedicated to Yahweh as Nazirites, they will be holy. They must let their hair grow long.
speaker: Narrator

text: While they are dedicated to Yahweh as Nazirites, they must never go near a dead body.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even if their own father, mother, brother, or sister dies, they must not make themselves unclean by going near them. Nazarites show their vow to Elohim with their long hair.
speaker: Narrator

text: As long as they are Nazirites, they will be holy to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Someone might suddenly drop dead next to a Nazirite and make the Nazirite’s hair unclean. Seven days later he must shave his head in order to be declared clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the eighth day he must bring two mourning doves or two young pigeons to the priest at the entrance to the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest will sacrifice one as an offering for sin and the other one as a burnt offering. The priest will make peace with the Lord for the person who touched the dead body. That same day the person must dedicate his head again.
speaker: Narrator

text: Once again he will dedicate himself to Yahweh as a Nazirite for the same length of time as before. He must bring a one-year-old male lamb as an offering for guilt. The first time period won’t count. He has to start over from when he became unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: “These are the instructions for Nazirites who complete their vows: They must come to the entrance of the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: They must bring these offerings to Yahweh: a one-year-old male lamb as a burnt offering, a one-year-old female lamb as an offering for sin, and a ram as a fellowship offering. All of these animals must have no defects.
speaker: Narrator

text: They must also bring a basket of unleavened bread containing some rings of bread made with olive oil and wafers of unleavened bread brushed with olive oil, along with other grain offerings and wine offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The priest will bring these offerings to Yahweh and make the offering for sin and the burnt offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will sacrifice the ram as a fellowship offering to Yahweh, offer the basket of unleavened bread along with it, and make the grain offerings and wine offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then the Nazirites will shave their heads at the entrance to the tent of meeting, take the hair as proof that they had made this vow, and put it on the fire under the fellowship offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then the priest will take one of the shoulders from a boiled ram, one ring of unleavened bread from the basket, and one wafer of unleavened bread and hand them to the Nazirites after they have shaved off their hair.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest will present them as an offering to Yahweh. They are holy and belong to the priest, along with the ram’s breast that is presented and the thigh that is given. After that, the Nazirites may drink wine.
speaker: Narrator

text: “These are the instructions for those who have vowed to bring their offerings to Yahweh because they were Nazirites. They must bring these offerings in addition to anything else they can afford. They must fulfill the requirements of these instructions for Nazirites and finish whatever they vowed to do.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell Aaron and his sons, ‘This is how you will bless the Israelites. Say to them:
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh will bless you and watch over you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh will smile on you and be kind to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh will look on you with favor and give you peace.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “So whenever they use my name to bless the Israelites, I will bless them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Moses finished setting up the tent, he anointed it and dedicated it and all the furnishings. He also anointed and dedicated the altar and all the utensils.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the leaders of Israel, the heads of the households—those tribal leaders who helped in the census—came to give their offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: They brought these gifts to Yahweh: six freight wagons and twelve oxen, one wagon from every two leaders and one ox from each leader. They brought them in front of the tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Accept these gifts from them to use in the work done for the tent of meeting. Give them to the Levites to use wherever they need these gifts for their work.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses took the wagons and the oxen and gave them to the Levites.
speaker: Narrator

text: He gave two wagons and four oxen to the Gershonites for the work they had to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: He gave four wagons and eight oxen to the Merarites for the work they had to do under the direction of Ithamar, son of the priest Aaron.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Moses gave none of these gifts to the Kohathites, because they took care of the holy things. They had to carry the holy things on their own shoulders.
speaker: Narrator

text: The leaders also brought offerings for the dedication of the altar when it was anointed. They presented their gifts in front of the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh said to Moses, “Each day a different leader will bring his gift for the dedication of the altar.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The one who brought his gifts on the first day was Nahshon, son of Amminadab, from the tribe of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: He brought a silver plate that weighed 3¼ pounds and a silver bowl that weighed 1¾ pounds, using the standard weight of the holy place. Each dish was filled with flour mixed with olive oil as a grain offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: He also brought a gold dish that weighed 4 ounces, filled with incense;
speaker: Narrator

text: a young bull, a ram, and a one-year-old male lamb as a burnt offering;
speaker: Narrator

text: a male goat as an offering for sin;
speaker: Narrator

text: and two bulls, five rams, five male goats, and five one-year-old male lambs as a fellowship offering. These were the gifts from Nahshon, son of Amminadab.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the second day Nethanel, son of Zuar, the leader from the tribe of Issachar, brought his gifts.

text: and two bulls, five rams, five male goats, and five one-year-old male lambs as a fellowship offering. These were the gifts from Pagiel, son of Ochran.
speaker: Narrator

speaker: Narrator

text: brought his gifts: a silver plate that weighed 3¼ pounds and a silver bowl that weighed 1¾ pounds using the standard weight of the holy place. Each dish was filled with flour mixed with olive oil as a grain offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: He also brought a gold dish that weighed 4 ounces, filled with incense;
speaker: Narrator

speaker: Narrator

text: a male goat as an offering for sin;
speaker: Narrator

text: and two bulls, five rams, five male goats, and five one-year-old male lambs as a fellowship offering. These were the gifts from Ahira, son of Enan.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the gifts from the leaders of Israel for the dedication of the altar when it was anointed: 12 silver plates, 12 silver bowls, and 12 gold dishes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each silver plate weighed 3¼ pounds, and each bowl weighed 1¾ pounds. Together all the silver dishes weighed 60 pounds, using the standard weight of the holy place.
speaker: Narrator

text: The 12 gold dishes filled with incense weighed 4 ounces each, using the standard weight of the holy place. Together all the gold dishes weighed about 3 pounds.
speaker: Narrator

text: The total number of animals for the burnt offerings was 12 young bulls, 12 rams, 12 one-year-old male lambs, along with their grain offerings. Twelve male goats were used as offerings for sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: The total number of animals for fellowship offerings was 24 bulls, 60 rams, 60 male goats, and 60 one-year-old male lambs. These were the gifts for the dedication of the altar after it was anointed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whenever Moses went into the tent of meeting to speak with Yahweh, he heard the voice speaking to him from above the throne of mercy on the ark containing the words of God’s promise, from between the two angels. This is how Yahweh spoke with Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Speak to Aaron and tell him: When you set up the seven lamps on the lamp stand, they should light up the area in front of it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Aaron set up the lamps on the lamp stand to light up the area in front of it, as Yahweh commanded Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is how the lamp stand was made: The whole lamp stand, from top to bottom, was hammered out of gold. It was made exactly like the one Yahweh had shown Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Separate the Levites from the rest of the Israelites, and make them clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what you must do to make them clean: Sprinkle them with water to take away their sins. Make them shave their whole bodies and wash their clothes. Then they will be clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: Next, they must take a young bull and the grain offering of flour mixed with olive oil that is offered with it. You must take a second young bull as an offering for sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bring the Levites to the front of the tent of meeting, and assemble the whole community of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then bring the Levites into Yahweh’s presence, and the Israelites will place their hands on them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron will present the Levites to Yahweh as an offering from the Israelites. Then they will be ready to do Yahweh’s work.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Levites will place their hands on the heads of the young bulls. Sacrifice one of them as an offering for sin and the other one as a burnt offering to Yahweh. These sacrifices will make peace with the Lord for the Levites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make the Levites stand in front of Aaron and his sons, and present them as an offering to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: In this way you will separate the Levites from the other Israelites, and the Levites will be mine.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Once you have made them clean and presented them as an offering, the Levites may come and do their work at the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will be the only Israelites given to me. I have taken them to be mine as substitutes for every firstborn male offspring of the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every firstborn in Israel, whether human or animal, is mine. The day I killed every firstborn male in Egypt, I set them apart as holy to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I have taken the Levites as substitutes for all the firstborn sons of the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Levites will be the only Israelites I give to Aaron and his sons. They will work for the Israelites at the tent of meeting. They will make peace with the Lord for the Israelites. Then no plague will strike the Israelites when they come near the holy place.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses, Aaron, and the whole community of Israel did what Yahweh commanded Moses to do to the Levites.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Levites performed the ceremonies to take away their sins and washed their clothes. Aaron presented them as an offering to Yahweh and made peace with the Lord for them in order to make them clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: After that, the Levites came and did their work at the tent of meeting in the presence of Aaron and his sons. They did as Yahweh had commanded Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “These are the instructions for the Levites: Men 25 years old or older are eligible to serve at the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when they’re 50 years old, they must retire from active service and not work anymore.
speaker: Narrator

text: They may assist the other Levites in their duties at the tent of meeting, but they may not do any regular work. This is how you will handle the Levites’ duties.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In the first month of the second year after the Israelites left Egypt, Yahweh spoke to Moses in the Desert of Sinai. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Israelites must celebrate the Passover at the same time every year.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must celebrate it on the fourteenth day of this month at dusk. Follow all the rules and regulations for the celebration of the Passover.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses told the Israelites to celebrate the Passover,
speaker: Narrator

text: and they celebrated it on the fourteenth day of the first month at dusk while they were in the Desert of Sinai. The Israelites did everything as Yahweh had commanded Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: But there were some men who had become unclean from touching a dead body, and they couldn’t celebrate the Passover that day. They came to Moses and Aaron
speaker: Narrator

text: and said, “We are unclean because we touched a dead body. Why won’t you let us bring our offerings to Yahweh at the same time the rest of the Israelites bring their offerings?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses answered them, “Wait here until I find out what Yahweh commands you to do.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Yahweh said to Moses, “Tell the Israelites:
speaker: Narrator

text: Suppose you or any of your descendants is unclean from touching a dead body or is away on a long trip. You may still celebrate the Passover.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will celebrate it on the fourteenth day of the second month at dusk. You must eat the Passover animal along with unleavened bread and bitter herbs.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must never leave any of the meat until morning or break any of the animal’s bones. You must follow all the rules for the Passover when you celebrate it.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you are clean and not on a trip and yet don’t bother to celebrate the Passover, you must be excluded from the people. You didn’t bring your offering to Yahweh at the right time. You must suffer the consequences for your sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Foreigners living with you may want to celebrate Yahweh’s Passover. They must follow these same rules and regulations. The same rules will apply to foreigners and native-born Israelites.”
speaker: Narrator

text: On the day the tent of the words of God’s promise was set up, the column of smoke covered it. From evening until morning, the smoke over the tent glowed like fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: The smoke always glowed this way. At night the smoke covering the tent glowed like fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whenever the smoke moved from the tent, the Israelites would break camp, and wherever it stopped, the Israelites would set up camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: At Yahweh’s command the Israelites would break camp, and at his command they would set up camp. As long as the column of smoke stayed over the tent, they would stay in the same place.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the smoke stayed over the tent for a long time, the Israelites obeyed Yahweh’s command and wouldn’t break camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: The same thing happened when the smoke stayed only a few days over the tent: At Yahweh’s command they would set up camp, and at Yahweh’s command they would break camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sometimes the column of smoke stayed only from evening until morning. When the smoke moved in the morning, they broke camp. Day or night, when the smoke moved, they broke camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whether it was two days, a month, or a year, as long as the column of smoke stayed over the tent, the Israelites would stay in the same place and not break camp. But when the smoke moved, they would break camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: At Yahweh’s command they set up camp, and at his command they broke camp. They obeyed the command that Yahweh had given through Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Make two trumpets out of hammered silver. Use them to call the community together and as a signal to break camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you blow both trumpets, the whole community will meet with you at the entrance to the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: If only one trumpet blows, the leaders, the heads of the divisions of Israel, will meet with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they hear the trumpet fanfare, the tribes that are camped on the east side will break camp first.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the trumpets sound a second fanfare, the tribes that are camped on the south will break camp. The fanfare is the signal to break camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when you gather the assembly, the trumpets will blow without sounding a fanfare.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Aaron, the priests, will blow the trumpets. This will be a permanent law for you and your descendants.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you go to war in your own country against an enemy who is oppressing you, the trumpets will sound a fanfare. Then Yahweh your Elohim will remember you and rescue you from your enemies.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also, on your festival days and on the first day of the month, blow the trumpets when you sacrifice your burnt offerings and fellowship offerings. The trumpets will be a reminder for you in Elohim’s presence. I am Yahweh your Elohim.”
speaker: Narrator

text: On the twentieth day of the second month of the second year, the column of smoke left the tent of the words of God’s promise.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Israelites moved from the Desert of Sinai and traveled from place to place until the column of smoke stopped in the Desert of Paran.
speaker: Narrator

text: This was the first time they moved, following the command that Yahweh had given through Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: With their flag in front, the armies led by Judah’s descendants broke camp first. Nahshon, son of Amminadab, was in command.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nethanel, son of Zuar, commanded the army of Issachar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eliab, son of Helon, commanded the army of Zebulun.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the tent of meeting was taken down, and the Gershonites and Merarites, who carried it, broke camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: With their flag in front, the armies led by Reuben’s descendants broke camp next. Elizur, son of Shedeur, was in command.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shelumiel, son of Zurishaddai, commanded the army of Simeon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eliasaph, son of Deuel, commanded the army of Gad.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Kohathites, who carried the holy things, broke camp. By the time they arrived, the tent of meeting would already be set up.
speaker: Narrator

text: With their flag in front, the armies led by Ephraim’s descendants broke camp next. Elisha, son of Ammihud, was in command.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gamaliel, son of Pedahzur, commanded the army of Manasseh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abidan, son of Gideoni, commanded the army of Benjamin.
speaker: Narrator

text: As a rear guard for the whole camp, the armies led by Dan’s descendants broke camp last with their flag in front. Ahiezer, son of Ammishaddai, was in command.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pagiel, son of Ochran, commanded the army of Asher.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahira, son of Enan, commanded the army of Naphtali.
speaker: Narrator

text: This was the order in which the Israelite armies broke camp when they went from place to place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to his brother-in-law Hobab, son of Reuel the Midianite, “We are going to the place Yahweh promised to give us. Come with us. We will be good to you, because Yahweh has promised good things to Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Hobab answered, “No, I won’t go. I want to go back to my own country where my relatives are.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Moses said, “Please don’t leave us. You know where we can set up camp in the desert, and you could be our guide.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you come with us, we will share with you all the good things Yahweh gives us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they left the mountain of Yahweh and traveled for three days. The ark of Yahweh’s promise went ahead of them a distance of three days’ journey to find them a place to rest.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh’s column of smoke was over them by day when they moved the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whenever the ark started to move, Moses would say,
“Arise, O Yahweh!
    Scatter your enemies!
        Make those who hate you run away from you!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
And whenever it stopped, he would say,
“Return, O Yahweh, to the countless thousands of Israel!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The people began complaining out loud to Yahweh about their troubles. When Yahweh heard them, he became angry, and fire from Yahweh began to burn among them. It destroyed some people on the outskirts of the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people cried out to Moses, Moses prayed to Yahweh, and the fire died down.
speaker: Narrator

text: That place was called Taberah [Fire] because fire from Yahweh burned among them there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some foreigners among the Israelites had a strong craving for other kinds of food. Even the Israelites started crying again and said, “If only we had meat to eat!
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember all the free fish we ate in Egypt and the cucumbers, watermelons, leeks, onions, and garlic we had?
speaker: Narrator

text: But now we’ve lost our appetite! Everywhere we look there’s nothing but manna!”
speaker: Narrator

text: (Manna was small like coriander seeds and looked like resin.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people would go around and gather it, then grind it in a handmill or crush it in a mortar. They would cook it in a pot or make round loaves of bread out of it. It tasted like rich pastry made with olive oil.
speaker: Narrator

text: When dew fell on the camp at night, manna fell with it.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses heard people from every family crying at the entrance to their tents. Yahweh became very angry, and Moses didn’t like it either.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he asked, “Yahweh, why have you brought me this trouble? How have I displeased you that you put the burden of all these people on me?
speaker: Narrator

text: Am I their mother? Did I give birth to them? Are you really asking me to carry them in my arms—as a nurse carries a baby—all the way to the land you promised their ancestors with an oath?
speaker: Narrator

text: Where can I get meat for all these people? They keep crying for me to give them meat to eat.
speaker: Narrator

text: I can’t take care of all these people by myself. This is too much work for me!
speaker: Narrator

text: If this is how you’re going to treat me, why don’t you just kill me? I can’t face this trouble anymore.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh answered Moses, “Bring me 70 Israelite men who you know are leaders and officers of the people. Take them to the tent of meeting, and have them stand with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I’ll come down and speak with you there. I’ll take some of the Ruach that is on you and put it on them. They will help you take care of the people. You won’t have to take care of the people alone.
speaker: Narrator

text: Tell the people to get ready for tomorrow. They must be set apart as holy. Then they will eat meat. I, Yahweh, heard them crying and saying, ‘If only we had meat to eat! We were better off in Egypt!’ So Yahweh will give them meat.
speaker: Narrator

text: They won’t eat it just for one or two days, or five, or ten, or twenty days,
speaker: Narrator

text: but for a whole month, until it comes out of their ears and they’re sick of it. This is because they rejected Yahweh who is here among them and cried in front of him, asking, ‘Why did we ever leave Egypt?’”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Moses said, “Here I am with 600,000 foot soldiers around me. Yet, you say, ‘I will give them meat to eat for a whole month!’
speaker: Narrator

text: Would they have enough if all the flocks and herds were butchered for them? Would they have enough if all the fish in the sea were caught for them?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh asked Moses, “Is there a limit to Yahweh’s power? Now you will see whether or not my words come true.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses went out and told the people what Yahweh said. He gathered 70 of the leaders of the people and had them stand around the tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Yahweh came down in the column of smoke and spoke with him. He took some of the Ruach that was on Moses and put it on the 70 leaders. When the Ruach came to rest on them, they prophesied, but they never prophesied again.
speaker: Narrator

text: Two men, named Eldad and Medad, had stayed in the camp. They were on the list with the other leaders but hadn’t gone with them to the tent. The Ruach came to rest on them, too, and they prophesied in the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then a young man ran and told Moses, “Eldad and Medad are prophesying in the camp.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joshua, son of Nun, who had been Moses’ assistant ever since he was a young man, spoke up and said, “Stop them, sir!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Moses asked him, “Do you think you need to stand up for me? I wish all Yahweh’s people were prophets and that Yahweh would put his Ruach on them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses and the leaders went back to the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh sent a wind from the sea that brought quails and dropped them all around the camp. There were quails on the ground about three feet deep as far as you could walk in a day in any direction.
speaker: Narrator

text: All that day and night and all the next day the people went out and gathered the quails. No one gathered less than 60 bushels. Then they spread the quails out all around the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: While the meat was still in their mouths—before they had even had a chance to chew it—Yahweh became angry with the people and struck them with a severe plague.
speaker: Narrator

text: That place was called Kibroth Hattaavah [Graves of Those Who Craved Meat] because there they buried the people who had a strong craving for meat.
speaker: Narrator

text: From Kibroth Hattaavah the people moved to Hazeroth, and they stayed there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Miriam and Aaron began to criticize Moses because he was married to a woman from Sudan.
speaker: Narrator

text: They asked, “Did Yahweh speak only through Moses? Didn’t he also speak through us?” Yahweh heard their complaint.
speaker: Narrator

text: (Moses was a very humble man, more humble than anyone else on earth.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Suddenly, Yahweh said to Moses, Aaron, and Miriam, “All three of you come to the tent of meeting.” So all three of them came.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Yahweh came down in the column of smoke and stood at the entrance to the tent. He called to Aaron and Miriam, and they both came forward.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Listen to my words: When there are prophets of Yahweh among you, I make myself known to them in visions or speak to them in dreams.
speaker: Narrator

text: But this is not the way I treat my servant Moses. He is the most faithful person in my household.
speaker: Narrator

text: I speak with him face to face, plainly and not in riddles. He even sees the form of Yahweh. Why weren’t you afraid to criticize my servant Moses?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh was angry with them, so he left.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the smoke left the tent, Miriam was covered with an infectious skin disease. She was as white as snow. Aaron turned to her and saw she was covered with the disease.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he said to Moses, “Please, sir, don’t punish us for this foolish sin we committed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t let her be like a stillborn baby that’s not completely developed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses cried to Yahweh, “Please, El, heal her!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh replied to Moses, “If her own father had spit in her face, wouldn’t she be excluded from the community for seven days? She must be put in isolation outside the camp for seven days. Then she can be brought back.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Miriam was put in isolation outside the camp for seven days. The people didn’t break camp until she was brought back.
speaker: Narrator

text: After that, the people moved from Hazeroth and set up camp in the Desert of Paran.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Send men to explore Canaan, which I’m giving to the Israelites. Send one leader from each of their ancestors’ tribes.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So at Yahweh’s command, Moses sent these men from the Desert of Paran. All of them were leaders of the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These are their names:
Shammua, son of Zaccur, from the tribe of Reuben;
speaker: Narrator

text: Shaphat, son of Hori, from the tribe of Simeon;
speaker: Narrator

text: Caleb, son of Jephunneh, from the tribe of Judah;
speaker: Narrator

text: Igal, son of Joseph, from the tribe of Issachar;
speaker: Narrator

text: Hoshea, son of Nun, from the tribe of Ephraim;
speaker: Narrator

text: Palti, son of Raphu, from the tribe of Benjamin;
speaker: Narrator

text: Gaddiel, son of Sodi, from the tribe of Zebulun;
speaker: Narrator

text: Gaddi, son of Susi, from the tribe of Joseph (that is, the tribe of Manasseh);
speaker: Narrator

text: Ammiel, son of Gemalli, from the tribe of Dan;
speaker: Narrator

text: Sethur, son of Michael, from the tribe of Asher;
speaker: Narrator

text: Nahbi, son of Vophsi, from the tribe of Naphtali;
speaker: Narrator

text: Geuel, son of Machi, from the tribe of Gad.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the names of the men Moses sent to explore the land. But Moses gave Hoshea, son of Nun, the name Joshua.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Moses sent them to explore Canaan, he told them, “Go through the Negev and then into the mountain region.
speaker: Narrator

text: See what the land is like and whether the people living there are strong or weak, few or many.
speaker: Narrator

text: Is the land they live in good or bad? Do their cities have walls around them or not?
speaker: Narrator

text: Is the soil rich or poor? Does the land have trees or not? Do your best to bring back some fruit from the land.” (It was the season when grapes were beginning to ripen.)
speaker: Narrator

text: So the men explored the land from the Desert of Zin to the border of Hamath.
speaker: Narrator

text: They went through the Negev and came to Hebron, where Ahiman, Sheshai, and Talmai lived. They are descendants of Anak. (Hebron was built seven years before Zoan in Egypt.)
speaker: Narrator

text: When they came to the Eshcol Valley, they cut off a branch with only one bunch of grapes on it. They carried it on a pole between two of them. They also brought some pomegranates and figs.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they called that valley Eshcol [Bunch of Grapes] because of the bunch of grapes the Israelites cut off there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Forty days later, they came back from exploring the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: They came back to Moses, Aaron, and the whole community of Israel at Kadesh in the Desert of Paran. They gave their report and showed them the fruit from the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what they reported to Moses: “We went to the land where you sent us. It really is a land flowing with milk and honey. Here’s some of its fruit.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the people who live there are strong, and the cities have walls and are very large. We even saw the descendants of Anak there.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Amalekites live in the Negev. The Hittites, Jebusites, and Amorites live in the mountain region. And the Canaanites live along the coast of the Mediterranean Sea and all along the Jordan River.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Caleb told the people to be quiet and listen to Moses. Caleb said, “Let’s go now and take possession of the land. We should be more than able to conquer it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the men who had gone with him said, “We can’t attack those people! They’re too strong for us!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they began to spread lies among the Israelites about the land they had explored. They said, “The land we explored is one that devours those who live there. All the people we saw there are very tall.
speaker: Narrator

text: We saw Nephilim there. (The descendants of Anak are Nephilim.) We felt as small as grasshoppers, and that’s how we must have looked to them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the people in the Israelite community raised their voices and cried out loud all that night.
speaker: Narrator

text: They complained to Moses and Aaron, “If only we had died in Egypt or this desert!
speaker: Narrator

text: Why is the Lord bringing us to this land—just to have us die in battle? Our wives and children will be taken as prisoners of war! Wouldn’t it be better for us to go back to Egypt?”
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to each other, “Let’s choose a leader and go back to Egypt.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Immediately, Moses and Aaron bowed with their faces touching the ground in front of the whole community of Israel assembled there.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the same time, two of those who had explored the land, Joshua (son of Nun) and Caleb (son of Jephunneh), tore their clothes in despair.
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to the whole community of Israel, “The land we explored is very good.
speaker: Narrator

text: If Yahweh is pleased with us, he will bring us into this land and give it to us. This is a land flowing with milk and honey!
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t rebel against Yahweh, and don’t be afraid of the people of the land. We will devour them like bread. They have no protection, and Yahweh is with us. So don’t be afraid of them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But when the whole community of Israel talked about stoning Moses and Aaron to death, they all saw the glory of Yahweh shining at the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh said to Moses, “How long will these people treat me with contempt? How long will they refuse to trust me in spite of all the miraculous signs I have done among them?
speaker: Narrator

text: I’ll strike them with a plague, I’ll destroy them, and I’ll make you into a nation larger and stronger than they are.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Moses said to Yahweh, “What if the Egyptians hear about it? (You used your power to take these people away from them.)
speaker: Narrator

text: What if the Egyptians tell the people who live in this land? Yahweh, they have already heard that you are with these people, that they have seen you with their own eyes, that your column of smoke stays over them, and that you go ahead of them in a column of smoke by day and in a column of fire by night.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you kill all these people at the same time, then the nations who have heard these reports about you will say,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Yahweh wasn’t able to bring these people into the land he promised them, so he slaughtered them in the desert.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Adonay, let your power be as great as when you said,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Yahweh . . . patient, forever loving. . . . He forgives wrongdoing and disobedience. . . . He never lets the guilty go unpunished, punishing children . . . for their parents’ sins to the third and fourth generation. . . .’
speaker: Narrator

text: By your great love, please forgive these people’s sins, as you have been forgiving them from the time they left Egypt until now.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh said, “I forgive them, as you have asked.
speaker: Narrator

text: But as I live and as the glory of Yahweh fills the whole earth, I solemnly swear that
speaker: Narrator

text: none of the people who saw my glory and the miraculous signs I did in Egypt and in the desert will see the land which I promised their ancestors. They have tested me now ten times and refused to obey me.
speaker: Narrator

text: None of those who treat me with contempt will see it!
speaker: Narrator

text: But because my servant Caleb has a different attitude and has wholeheartedly followed me, I’ll bring him to the land he already explored. His descendants will possess it.
speaker: Narrator

text: (The Amalekites and Canaanites are living in the valleys.) Tomorrow you must turn around, go back into the desert, and follow the road that goes to the Red Sea.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Yahweh said to Moses and Aaron,
speaker: Narrator

text: “How long must I put up with this wicked community that keeps complaining about me? I’ve heard the complaints the Israelites are making about me.
speaker: Narrator

text: So tell them, ‘As I live, declares Yahweh, I solemnly swear I will do everything to you that you said I would do.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your bodies will drop dead in this desert. All of you who are at least 20 years old, who were registered and listed, and who complained about me will die.
speaker: Narrator

text: I raised my hand and swore an oath to give you this land to live in. But none of you will enter it except Caleb (son of Jephunneh) and Joshua (son of Nun).
speaker: Narrator

text: You said your children would be taken as prisoners of war. Instead, I will bring them into the land you rejected, and they will enjoy it.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, your bodies will drop dead in this desert.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your children will be shepherds in the desert for 40 years. They will suffer for your unfaithfulness until the last of your bodies lies dead in the desert.
speaker: Narrator

text: For 40 days you explored the land. So for 40 years—one year for each day—you will suffer for your sins and know what it means for me to be against you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: I, Yahweh, have spoken. I swear I will do these things to all the people in this whole wicked community who have joined forces against me. They will meet their end in this desert. Here they will die!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the men Moses sent to explore the land died in front of Yahweh from a plague.
speaker: Narrator

text: They died because they had returned and made the whole community complain about Moses by spreading lies about the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Of all the men who went to explore the land, only Joshua (son of Nun) and Caleb (son of Jephunneh) survived.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Moses told these things to all the Israelites, the people mourned bitterly, as if someone had died.
speaker: Narrator

text: Early the next morning they headed into the mountain region. They said, “We have sinned. Now we’ll go to the place Yahweh promised.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Moses asked, “Why are you disobeying Yahweh’s command? Your plan won’t work!
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t go! You will be defeated by your enemies because Yahweh is not with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Amalekites and Canaanites are there, and you will die in battle. Now that you have turned away from Yahweh, Yahweh will not be with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But they headed into the mountain region anyway, even though the ark of Yahweh’s promise and Moses stayed in the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Amalekites and Canaanites who lived there came down from those mountains, attacked the Israelites, and defeated them at Hormah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Speak to the Israelites and tell them: Once you’re settled in the land I’m giving you,
speaker: Narrator

text: you may bring offerings by fire to Yahweh. They may be burnt offerings or any other kind of sacrifice. They may be offered to fulfill a vow, as a freewill offering, or as one of your festival offerings. They may be cattle, sheep, or goats—offerings that are a soothing aroma to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whoever brings the offering must also give Yahweh a grain offering of eight cups of flour mixed with one quart of olive oil.
speaker: Narrator

text: With each sheep or goat for the burnt offering or any other sacrifice, also give an offering of one quart of wine.
speaker: Narrator

text: “With a ram, give a grain offering of 16 cups of flour mixed with 1¼ quarts of oil
speaker: Narrator

text: and an offering of 1¼ quarts of wine. Offer them as a soothing aroma to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Suppose you sacrifice a young bull as a burnt offering to Yahweh or make any other kind of sacrifice—to keep a vow or as a fellowship offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: Offer with the young bull a grain offering of 24 cups of flour mixed with two quarts of olive oil.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also give an offering of two quarts of wine. It is an offering by fire, a soothing aroma to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do this for each bull, each ram, and each sheep or goat.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do it for each animal, however many you sacrifice.
speaker: Narrator

text: All native-born Israelites must do it this way when they bring an offering by fire, a soothing aroma to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Suppose foreigners are visiting you or living among you in future generations. If they bring an offering by fire, a soothing aroma to Yahweh, they must do as you do.
speaker: Narrator

text: There is one law for the whole assembly: for you and foreigners who are living with you. It is a permanent law for future generations. As far as Yahweh is concerned, you and foreigners are the same.
speaker: Narrator

text: The instructions and rules are the same for you as well as foreigners who are living with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Speak to the Israelites and tell them: When you enter the land where I’m taking you
speaker: Narrator

text: and eat any of the food from the land, give some of it as a contribution to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shape one part of your dough into a ring the same way you do with the contribution you make from the threshing floor.
speaker: Narrator

text: For generations to come, you must give one part of your dough as a contribution to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Suppose you unintentionally do something wrong by not obeying all these commands Yahweh gave Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: (Everything Yahweh commanded you through Moses holds as true for generations to come as it did the day Yahweh gave the commands.)
speaker: Narrator

text: If it was unintentional and no one else knows about it, the whole community must sacrifice a young bull as a burnt offering, a soothing aroma to Yahweh, along with the proper grain and wine offerings, and a male goat as an offering for sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest will make peace with the Lord for the whole community of Israel. Then they will be forgiven because the wrongdoing was unintentional and they brought these two offerings to Yahweh for their sin: an offering by fire and an offering for sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the whole community of Israel will be forgiven, including foreigners who are living among them, since all the people were involved in the unintentional wrongdoing.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If one person unintentionally does something wrong, a one-year-old female goat must be sacrificed as an offering for sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest will offer the sacrifice to make peace with Yahweh for that person, and that person will be forgiven.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must give the same instructions to everyone who does something wrong unintentionally, whether they are native-born Israelites or not.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But any native-born Israelite or foreigner who deliberately does something wrong insults Yahweh and must be excluded from the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: That person has despised the word of Yahweh and broken Yahweh’s command. He must be excluded completely. He remains guilty.”
speaker: Narrator

text: While the Israelites were in the desert, they found a man gathering wood on the day of worship.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who found him gathering wood brought him to Moses and Aaron and the whole community.
speaker: Narrator

text: They kept him in custody until they decided what to do with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Yahweh said to Moses, “This man must be put to death. The whole community must take him outside the camp and stone him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the whole community took him outside the camp and stoned him to death, as Yahweh commanded Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Speak to the Israelites and tell them: For generations to come they must wear tassels on the corners of their clothes with violet threads in each tassel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whenever you look at the threads in the tassel, you will remember all Yahweh’s commands and obey them. Then you won’t do whatever you want and go after whatever you see, as if you were chasing after prostitutes.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will remember to obey all my commands, and you will be holy to your Elohim.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am Yahweh your Elohim, who brought you out of Egypt to be your Elohim. I am Yahweh your Elohim.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Korah (son of Izhar), Dathan and Abiram (sons of Eliab), and On (son of Peleth) dared to challenge Moses. (Korah was a descendant of Kohath and Levi. Dathan, Abiram, and On were descendants of Reuben.)
speaker: Narrator

text: These four men were joined by 250 Israelite men, well-known leaders of the community, chosen by the assembly.
speaker: Narrator

text: They came together to confront Moses and Aaron and said to them, “You’ve gone far enough! Everyone in the whole community is holy, and Yahweh is among them. Why do you set yourselves above Yahweh’s assembly?”
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as Moses heard this, he bowed with his face touching the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to Korah and all his followers, “In the morning Yahweh will show who belongs to him, who is holy, and who it is that he will allow to come near him. Only the person Yahweh chooses will be allowed to come near him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Korah, you and all your followers must do this tomorrow: Take incense burners,
speaker: Narrator

text: and put burning coals and incense in them in Yahweh’s presence. Then Yahweh will choose the man who is holy. You’ve gone far enough!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses also said to Korah, “Listen, you Levites!
speaker: Narrator

text: Isn’t it enough for you that the Elohim of Israel has separated you from the rest of the community of Israel? Yahweh has brought you near himself to do the work for his tent and stand in front of the community to serve them.
speaker: Narrator

text: He has brought you and all the other Levites near himself, but now you demand to be priests.
speaker: Narrator

text: So you and all your followers have joined forces against Yahweh! Who is Aaron that you should complain about him?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses sent for Dathan and Abiram, sons of Eliab. But they said, “We won’t come!
speaker: Narrator

text: Isn’t it enough that you brought us out of a land flowing with milk and honey only to kill us in the desert? Do you also have to order us around?
speaker: Narrator

text: Certainly you haven’t brought us into a land flowing with milk and honey or given us any fields and vineyards to own. Do you think you can still pull the wool over our eyes? We won’t come.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses became angry and said to Yahweh, “Don’t accept their offering. I haven’t taken anything from them, not even a donkey. And I haven’t mistreated any of them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to Korah, “Tomorrow you and all your followers must come into Yahweh’s presence. Aaron will also be there with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each man will take his incense burner and put incense in it. They will offer all 250 incense burners to Yahweh. Then you and Aaron offer your incense burners.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So each man took his incense burner, put burning coals and incense in it, and stood with Moses and Aaron at the entrance to the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Korah had gathered all his followers—those who opposed Moses and Aaron—at the entrance to the tent of meeting, the glory of Yahweh appeared to the whole group.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh said to Moses and Aaron,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Move away from these men, and I’ll destroy them in an instant.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Immediately, they bowed with their faces touching the ground and said, “O El, you are the Elohim who gives the breath of life to everyone! If one man sins, will you be angry with the whole community?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Yahweh said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell the community: Move away from the tents of Korah, Dathan, and Abiram.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses got up and went to Dathan and Abiram, and the leaders of Israel followed him.
speaker: Narrator
