text: He said to the community, “Move away from the tents of these wicked men. Don’t touch anything that belongs to them, or you’ll be swept away because of all their sins.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they moved away from the tents of Korah, Dathan, and Abiram. Dathan and Abiram had come out and were standing at the entrances to their tents with their wives and children.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said, “This is how you will know that Yahweh sent me to do all these things and that it wasn’t my idea:
speaker: Narrator

text: If these men die like all other people—if they die a natural death—then Yahweh hasn’t sent me.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if Yahweh does something totally new—if the ground opens up, swallows them and everything that belongs to them, and they go down alive to their graves—then you’ll know that these men have treated Yahweh with contempt.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as he had finished saying all this, the ground under them split,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the earth opened up to swallow them, their families, the followers of Korah, and all their property.
speaker: Narrator

text: They went down alive to their graves with everything that belonged to them. The ground covered them, and so they disappeared from the assembly.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the Israelites around them ran away when they heard their screams. They thought the ground would swallow them, too.
speaker: Narrator

text: Fire came from Yahweh and consumed the 250 men who were offering incense.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Yahweh said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell Eleazar, son of the priest Aaron, to take the incense burners out of the fire and scatter the coals and incense somewhere else, because the incense burners have become holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: The incense burners of these men who sinned and lost their lives are holy, because they were offered to Yahweh. Hammer them into thin metal sheets to cover the altar. This will be a sign to the Israelites.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the priest Eleazar took the bronze incense burners which had been brought by those who had been burned to death. The incense burners were then hammered into thin metal sheets to cover the altar,
speaker: Narrator

text: following the command that Yahweh had given through Moses. The bronze-covered altar will remind Israel that no one but a descendant of Aaron can come near to burn incense to Yahweh. Everyone else will die like Korah and his followers.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day the whole community of Israel complained to Moses and Aaron. They said, “You have killed Yahweh’s people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The community came together to confront Moses and Aaron. When they turned toward the tent of meeting, they saw the smoke covering it, and the glory of Yahweh appeared.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses and Aaron went to the front of the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Get away from these people, and let me destroy them in an instant!” Immediately, they bowed with their faces touching the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to Aaron, “Take your incense burner, put burning coals from the altar and incense in it, and go quickly into the community to make peace with the Lord for the people. Yahweh is showing his anger; a plague has started.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron took his incense burner, as Moses told him, and ran into the middle of the assembly, because the plague had already begun among the people. He put incense on the incense burner to make peace with the Lord for the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: He stood between those who had died and those who were still alive, and the plague stopped.
speaker: Narrator

text: Still, 14,700 died from the plague in addition to those who had died because of Korah.
speaker: Narrator

text: By the time Aaron came back to Moses at the entrance to the tent of meeting, the plague had stopped.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Speak to the Israelites, and get 12 staffs from them, one from the leader of each of their tribes. Write each man’s name on his staff.
speaker: Narrator

text: Write Aaron’s name on the staff for Levi because there must be one staff for the head of each tribe.
speaker: Narrator

text: Put them in the tent of meeting where I meet with you, in front of the words of my promise.
speaker: Narrator

text: The staff from the man I choose will begin to grow. In this way I will silence the frequent complaints the Israelites make against you and Aaron.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses spoke to the Israelites. Their leaders gave him 12 staffs, one from the leader of each of their tribes. Aaron’s staff was among them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses put the staffs in Yahweh’s presence in the tent of the words of God’s promise.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day Moses went into the tent. He found that Aaron’s staff for the tribe of Levi had not only begun to grow, but it had also blossomed and produced ripe almonds.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses brought out the staffs fromYahweh’s presence and showed them to all the Israelites. They looked at them, and each man took his staff.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh said to Moses, “Put Aaron’s staff back in front of the words of my promise, and keep it there as a sign to warn any other rebels. Then you will stop their complaints about me, and they won’t die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses did exactly what Yahweh commanded him to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites said to Moses, “Now we’re going to die! We’re lost! We’re all lost!
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone who comes near Yahweh’s tent will die! Are we all going to die?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh said to Aaron, “You, your sons, and your family will be responsible for any sins against the holy place. You and your sons will also be responsible for any sins you commit when you work as priests.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bring the other Levites from your ancestor’s tribe to join you and help you and your sons serve in front of the tent of the words of my promise.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will work for you, doing whatever work is necessary for the whole tent. But they must not come near the altar or the furnishings in the holy place, or they will die, and you will die, too.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will join you and do whatever work is necessary for the tent of meeting, including all the maintenance work for the tent. But no one else may come near you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must be in charge of the work done at the holy place and at the altar. Then I won’t show my anger against the Israelites again.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have chosen the other Levites from among the Israelites to help you. They are a gift given to Yahweh to do whatever work is necessary at the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: Only you and your sons may do the work of priests—everything done at the altar and under the canopy. This is my gift to you: You may serve me as priests. Anyone else who comes near the holy place to do this work must die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh said to Aaron, “I am putting you in charge of all the contributions given to me. I am giving you and your descendants all the holy gifts from the Israelites as your share. These contributions will always be yours.
speaker: Narrator

text: That part of the most holy offerings which is not burned belongs to you. It may come from a grain offering, an offering for sin, or a guilt offering. Whatever is brought to me as a most holy offering will belong to you and your sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eat it in a most holy place. Any male may eat it. You must consider it holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The contributions that come as gifts taken from the offerings presented by the Israelites are also yours. I am giving these to you, your sons, and your daughters. They will always be yours. Anyone in your household who is clean may eat them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I am also giving you the first of the produce they give Yahweh: the best of all the olive oil and the best of the new wine and fresh grain.
speaker: Narrator

text: The first of all produce harvested in their land that they bring to Yahweh is yours. Anyone in your household who is clean may eat it.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Anything in Israel that is claimed by the Lord is yours.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every firstborn male, human or animal, that is brought to Yahweh is yours. But you must buy back every firstborn son and the firstborn male of any unclean animal.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they are one month old, you must buy them back at the fixed price of two ounces of silver, using the standard weight of the holy place.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But you must never buy back a firstborn ox, sheep, or goat. They are holy. Throw the blood from these animals against the altar, and burn the fat as an offering by fire, a soothing aroma to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the meat is yours, like the breast and the right thigh that are presented.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am giving you, your sons, and your daughters all the holy contributions the Israelites bring to Yahweh. These contributions will always be yours. It is an everlasting promise of salt in Yahweh’s presence for you and your descendants.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh said to Aaron, “You will have no land or property of your own as the other Israelites will have. I am your possession and your property among the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I am giving the Levites one-tenth of every Israelite’s income. This is in return for the work they do at the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: The other Israelites must never again come near the tent of meeting. Otherwise, they’ll suffer the consequences of their sin and die.
speaker: Narrator

text: Only the Levites will do the work at the tent of meeting. They will be responsible for their own sins. This is a permanent law for future generations. They will own no property as the other Israelites will.
speaker: Narrator

text: Instead, I will give the Levites what the Israelites contribute to Yahweh—one-tenth of the Israelites’ income. This is why I said about them, ‘They will own no property as the other Israelites do.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Speak to the Levites and say to them: You will take one-tenth of the Israelites’ income which I’m giving you as your property. When you do, you must contribute one-tenth of that income as your contribution to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your contribution will be considered to be grain from the threshing floor or juice from the winepress.
speaker: Narrator

text: So you, too, will contribute one-tenth of your income to Yahweh out of all that you receive from the Israelites’ income. You will give Yahweh’s contribution to the priest Aaron.
speaker: Narrator

text: Out of all the gifts you receive, you must contribute the best and holiest parts to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Also tell them: When you contribute the best part, your contribution will be considered to be produce from the threshing floor or winepress.
speaker: Narrator

text: So you and your households may eat it anywhere, because it’s the wages you receive for your work at the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you contribute the best part, you won’t suffer the consequences of any sin. You won’t be dishonoring the holy offerings given by the Israelites, and you won’t die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh said to Moses and Aaron,
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what Yahweh’s teachings have commanded: Tell the Israelites to bring you a red cow that is perfect, with no defects. Also, it must never have worn a yoke.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give it to the priest Eleazar. It must be taken outside the camp and slaughtered in his presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest Eleazar will take some of the blood with his finger and sprinkle it seven times toward the front of the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the entire cow (the skin, meat, blood, and excrement) will be burned while he watches.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest will take some cedar wood, a hyssop sprig, and some red yarn and throw them onto the burning cow.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest must then wash his clothes and his body. After that, he may go into the camp. But he will be unclean until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: The person who burned the calf must also wash his clothes and his body. He, too, will be unclean until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: “A man who is clean will collect the ashes from the cow and put them in a clean place outside the camp. They will be kept by the community of Israel and used in the water that takes away uncleanness. The cow is an offering for sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: The person who collected the ashes from the cow must also wash his clothes. He will be unclean until evening. This will be a permanent law for the Israelites and for the foreigners who live with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Whoever touches the dead body of any human being will be unclean for seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: The unclean person must use this water on the third day and the seventh day to take away his sin. Then he will be clean. But if he doesn’t use this water on the third day and the seventh day, he will not be clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whoever touches the dead body of a human being and doesn’t use this water to take away his sin makes Yahweh’s tent unclean. That person must be excluded from Israel, because the water that takes away uncleanness wasn’t sprinkled on him. He is unclean; his uncleanness stays with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: “These are your instructions for when a person dies in a tent: Everyone who goes into the tent and everyone who is in the tent will be unclean for seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every container without a lid fastened on it is unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Whoever is outdoors and touches someone who was killed or has died naturally or anyone who touches a human bone or a grave will be unclean for seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what you must do for people who become unclean from touching a dead body. Put some of the ashes from the red cow that was burned as an offering for sin into a container. Then pour fresh water on them.
speaker: Narrator

text: A person who is clean will take a sprig of hyssop, dip it in the water, and sprinkle the tent, all the furnishings, and all the people who were in the tent with the dead body. He must also sprinkle any person who has touched a human bone or a grave and any person who has touched someone who has been killed or who has died naturally.
speaker: Narrator

text: A person who is clean will sprinkle these types of unclean people on the third day and the seventh day. On the seventh day the clean person will finish taking away their sins. Then they must wash their clothes and bodies, and in the evening they will be clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if the person who becomes unclean doesn’t have his sin taken away, that person must be excluded from the assembly. He has made the holy place of Yahweh unclean. The water to take away uncleanness wasn’t sprinkled on him. He is unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This will be a permanent law for them.
“Whoever sprinkles the water to take away uncleanness must wash his clothes. And whoever touches this water will be unclean until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anything that an unclean person touches becomes unclean, and the person who touches it will be unclean until evening.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In the first month the whole community of Israel came into the Desert of Zin, and they stayed at Kadesh. Miriam died and was buried there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Since the community was without water, they came together to confront Moses and Aaron.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people complained to Moses and said, “If only we had died when the other Israelites died in Yahweh’s presence!
speaker: Narrator

text: Did you bring Yahweh’s assembly into this desert just to have us and our animals die here?
speaker: Narrator

text: Why did you make us leave Egypt and bring us into this terrible place? This is no place to plant crops. Even figs, grapes, and pomegranates won’t grow here. And there’s no water to drink!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses and Aaron went from the assembly to the entrance of the tent of meeting. Immediately, they bowed with their faces touching the ground, and the glory of Yahweh appeared to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Take your staff, then you and your brother Aaron gather the community. Right before their eyes, tell the rock to give up its water. In this way you will give the community water from the rock for them and their animals to drink.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses took his staff out of the tent in Yahweh’s presence as he had been commanded.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses and Aaron assembled the community in front of the rock and said to them, “Listen, you rebels, must we bring water out of this rock for you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses raised his hand and hit the rock twice with the staff. Water came pouring out, and all the people and their animals drank.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Yahweh said to Moses and Aaron, “You didn’t trust me! You didn’t show the Israelites how holy I am! So you will not bring this congregation into the land I’m giving them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: This was the oasis of Meribah [Complaining], where the Israelites complained about Yahweh and where he showed them he was holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses sent messengers from Kadesh to the king of Edom. He said, “This is what your brother Israel says: You know all the hardships we’ve had.
speaker: Narrator

text: Our ancestors went to Egypt, and we lived there for many years. The Egyptians mistreated us and our ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When we cried out to Yahweh, he heard us, sent a messenger, and brought us out of Egypt.
“Now we’re here in Kadesh, a city on the edge of your territory.
speaker: Narrator

text: Please let us go through your country. We won’t go through any of your fields or vineyards, or drink any of the water from your wells. We’ll stay on the king’s highway and never leave it until we’ve passed through your territory.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Edomites answered, “You may not pass through our country. If you try, we’ll come out and attack you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites replied, “We’ll stay on the main road, and if we or our livestock drink any of your water, we’ll pay for it. We want to pass through on foot. That’s all.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Edomites said, “You may not pass through.” Then they came out and attacked with many well-armed troops.
speaker: Narrator

text: Since the Edomites refused to let Israel go through their territory, the Israelites turned around and went a different way.
speaker: Narrator

text: The whole community of Israel left Kadesh and came to Mount Hor.
speaker: Narrator

text: At Mount Hor, near the border of Edom, Yahweh said to Moses and Aaron,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Aaron must now join his ancestors in death, since he cannot enter the land I’m giving the Israelites. This is because you both rebelled against my command at the oasis of Meribah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bring Aaron and his son Eleazar up on Mount Hor.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take off Aaron’s priestly clothes, and put them on his son Eleazar. Then Aaron will die there and join his ancestors.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses did as Yahweh commanded. The whole community saw them go up on Mount Hor.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses took off Aaron’s priestly clothes and put them on his son Eleazar. Aaron died there on top of the mountain. Then Moses and Eleazar came down from the mountain.
speaker: Narrator

text: The whole community saw that Aaron had died, and all the Israelites mourned for Aaron 30 days.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Canaanite king of Arad, who lived in the Negev, heard that the Israelites were coming on the road to Atharim, he fought them and took some of them as prisoners.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Israelites made this vow to Yahweh: “If you will hand these people over to us, we’ll destroy their cities because you’ve claimed them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh listened to the Israelites and handed the Canaanites over to them. They destroyed the Canaanites and their cities. So they called the place Hormah [Claimed for Destruction].
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they moved from Mount Hor, following the road that goes to the Red Sea, in order to get around Edom. The people became impatient on the trip
speaker: Narrator

text: and criticized Elohim and Moses. They said, “Why did you make us leave Egypt—just to let us die in the desert? There’s no bread or water, and we can’t stand this awful food!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Yahweh sent poisonous snakes among the people. They bit the people, and many of the Israelites died.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people came to Moses and said, “We sinned when we criticized Yahweh and you. Pray to Yahweh so that he will take the snakes away from us.” So Moses prayed for the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh said to Moses, “Make a snake, and put it on a pole. Anyone who is bitten can look at it and live.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses made a bronze snake and put it on a pole. People looked at the bronze snake after they were bitten, and they lived.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites moved and set up camp at Oboth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Next they moved from Oboth and set up camp at Iye Abarim in the desert west of Moab.
speaker: Narrator

text: From there they moved and set up camp at the Zered River.
speaker: Narrator

text: They moved from there and set up camp on the other side of the Arnon Valley in the desert that extends into Amorite territory. (The Arnon Valley is the border between Moab and the Amorites.)
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is how it’s described in the Book of the Wars of Yahweh:
“. . . Waheb in Suphah and the valleys,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Arnon and the slopes of the valleys
    that go down to the site of Ar
        and lie along the border of Moab. . . .”
speaker: Narrator

text: From there they went to Beer [Well]. This is the well where Yahweh said to Moses, “Gather the people, and I will give them water.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Israel sang this song about the well:
“Make your water spring up!
    Sing to the well,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the well dug by princes,
    dug out by the nobles of the people
        with their scepters and staffs.”
From the desert they went to Mattanah,
speaker: Narrator

text: and from Mattanah to Nahaliel, and from Nahaliel to Bamoth,
speaker: Narrator

text: and from Bamoth to the valley in Moab where Mount Pisgah overlooks Jeshimon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Israel sent messengers to say to King Sihon of the Amorites,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Let us go through your country. We won’t go through any of your fields or vineyards or drink any of the water from your wells. We’ll stay on the king’s highway until we’ve passed through your territory.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Sihon wouldn’t let Israel pass through his territory. Sihon gathered all his troops and came out into the desert to attack Israel. When Sihon’s troops came to Jahaz, they fought against Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Israel defeated them in battle and took possession of their land from the Arnon Valley to the Jabbok River. They stopped at the border of the Ammon because it was fortified.
speaker: Narrator

text: Israel took all those Amorite cities, including Heshbon and all its villages, and lived in them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Heshbon was the city of King Sihon of the Amorites. He had fought the former king of Moab and had taken all his land up to the Arnon Valley.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is why the poets say:
“Come to Heshbon! Rebuild it!
    Restore Sihon’s city!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Fire came out of Heshbon,
    flames from Sihon’s city.
        They destroyed Ar of Moab,
            the rulers of Arnon’s worship sites.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How horrible it is for you, Moab!
You are destroyed, you people of the god Chemosh.
    Chemosh let his sons become refugees
        and he let his daughters become prisoners
            of King Sihon of the Amorites.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But we shot the Amorites full of arrows.
    From Heshbon to Dibon they all died.
        We destroyed everyone and everything
            between Nophah and Medeba.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Israel settled in the land of the Amorites.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Moses sent spies to Jazer, the Israelites captured its cities and villages and forced out the Amorites who were there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they turned and followed the road that goes to Bashan. King Og of Bashan and all his troops came out to fight the Israelites at Edrei.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh said to Moses, “Don’t be afraid of him. I’ll hand him, all his troops, and his land over to you. Do to him what you did to King Sihon of the Amorites, who ruled in Heshbon.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites defeated him, his sons, and all his troops, leaving no survivors. And they took possession of his land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Israelites moved and set up camp across from Jericho, on the plains of Moab east of the Jordan River.
speaker: Narrator

text: Balak, son of Zippor, saw all that Israel had done to the Amorites.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Moabites were very afraid because there were so many Israelites. Besides, the Moabites couldn’t stand these people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So the Moabites said to the leaders of Midian, “All those people will eventually eat up everything around us the same way an ox eats up the grass in a field.”
At that time Balak, son of Zippor, was king of Moab.
speaker: Narrator

text: He sent messengers to summon Balaam, son of Beor, who was at Pethor, on the Euphrates River, in the land where his people lived. Balak’s message was, “A nation has just come here from Egypt. They’ve spread out all over the countryside and are setting up their camp here in front of me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Please come and curse these people for me, because they are too strong for me. Maybe then I’ll be able to defeat them and force them out of the country. I know that whomever you bless is blessed and whomever you curse is cursed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The leaders of Moab and Midian left, taking money with them to pay for Balaam’s services. They came to Balaam and told him what Balak had said.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Spend the night here,” Balaam said to them, “and I’ll report to you what Yahweh tells me.” So the princes of Moab stayed with Balaam.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elohim came to Balaam and asked, “Who are these men with you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam answered, “Balak, son of King Zippor of Moab, sent them with this message:
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Some people have just come from Egypt and are spreading out all over the countryside. Now come and curse them for me. Maybe I’ll be able to fight them and force them out.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Elohim said to Balaam, “Don’t go with them! Don’t curse these people, because they are blessed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Balaam got up in the morning, he said to Balak’s princes, “Go back to your own country, because Yahweh has refused to let me go with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Moabite princes went back to Balak and said, “Balaam refused to come with us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balak sent a larger group of more highly respected princes.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they came to Balaam, they said to him, “This is what Balak, son of Zippor, says: Don’t let anything keep you from coming to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will make sure you are richly rewarded, and I will do whatever you ask. Please, come and curse these people for me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Balaam answered Balak’s servants, “Even if Balak gave me his palace filled with silver and gold, I couldn’t disobey the command of Yahweh my Elohim no matter whether the request was important or not.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, why don’t you stay here tonight, as the others did, and I’ll find out what else Yahweh may have to tell me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: That night Elohim came to Balaam and said, “If these men have come to summon you, go with them, but do only what I tell you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Balaam got up in the morning, he saddled his donkey and left with the Moabite princes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elohim became angry that he was going. So the Messenger of Yahweh stood in the road to stop him. Balaam was riding on his donkey, accompanied by his two servants.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the donkey saw the Messenger of Yahweh standing in the road with his sword drawn, the donkey turned off the road into a field. Balaam hit the donkey to get it back on the road.
speaker: Narrator

text: Where the road went through the vineyards, it was narrow, with stone walls on both sides. Now the Messenger of Yahweh stood there.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the donkey saw the Messenger of Yahweh, it moved over and pinned Balaam’s foot against the wall. So Balaam hit the donkey again.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Messenger of Yahweh moved ahead and stood in a narrower place where there was no room to turn to the right or the left.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the donkey saw the Messenger of Yahweh, it lay down under Balaam. Balaam became so angry he hit the donkey with his stick.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Yahweh made the donkey speak, and it asked Balaam, “What have I done to make you hit me three times?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam answered, “You’ve made a fool of me! If I had a sword in my hand, I’d kill you right now.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The donkey said to Balaam, “I’m your own donkey. You’ve always ridden me. Have I ever done this to you before?”
“No,” he answered.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Yahweh let Balaam see the Messenger of Yahweh who was standing in the road with his sword drawn. So Balaam knelt, bowing with his face touching the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Messenger of Yahweh asked him, “Why have you hit your donkey three times like this? I’ve come here to stop you because the trip you’re taking is evil.
speaker: Narrator

text: The donkey saw me and turned away from me these three times. If it had not turned away from me, I would certainly have killed you by now but spared the donkey.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam said to the Messenger of Yahweh, “I’ve sinned. I didn’t know you were standing there in the road to stop me. If you still think this trip is evil, I’ll go back.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Messenger of Yahweh said to Balaam, “Go with the men, but say only what I tell you.” So Balaam went with Balak’s princes.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Balak heard that Balaam had come, he went out to meet him at Ir Moab, in the region of the Arnon Valley, right on the border of Moab.
speaker: Narrator

text: Balak said to Balaam, “Why didn’t you come when I summoned you? You knew I’d be able to reward you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam replied, “Well, I’ve come to you now. But I can’t say whatever I want to. I can only say what Elohim tells me to say.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam went with Balak to Kiriath Huzoth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Balak sacrificed cattle, sheep, and goats, and sent some of the meat to Balaam and the princes who were with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next morning Balak took Balaam up to Bamoth Baal. From there he could see the outskirts of the Israelites’ camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam said to Balak, “Build seven altars here, and prepare seven bulls and seven rams for me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balak did what Balaam told him, and the two of them offered a bull and a ram on each altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam said to Balak, “Stay here beside your burnt offering while I’m gone. Maybe Yahweh will come and meet with me. I will tell you whatever he reveals to me.” Then Balaam went off to a higher place where there were no trees.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elohim came to him, and Balaam said, “I have set up seven altars, and I offered a bull and a ram on each altar.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh told Balaam, “Go back to Balak, and give him my message.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he went back to Balak and found him standing beside his burnt offering with all the princes of Moab.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Balaam delivered this message:
“Balak brought me from Aram.
The king of Moab summoned me from the eastern mountains.
    ‘Come, curse Jacob for me,’ he said.
    ‘Come, condemn Israel.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
How can I curse those whom El hasn’t cursed?
How can I condemn those whom Yahweh hasn’t condemned?
speaker: Narrator

text:
I see them from the top of rocky cliffs,
    I look at them from the hills.
        I see a nation that lives by itself,
            people who do not consider themselves
                to be like other nations.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The descendants of Jacob are like specks of dust.
    Who can count them
        or number even one-fourth of the people of Israel?
Let me die the death of innocent people.
Let my end be like theirs.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balak said to Balaam, “What have you done to me? I brought you here to curse my enemies, but all you’ve done is bless them!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam answered, “I must say what Yahweh tells me to say.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Balak said to him, “Please come with me to another place, where you can see the Israelites. You will see only some of them, not all of them. Curse them for me from there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he took him to the Field of Zophim on top of Mount Pisgah, where he built seven altars. He offered a bull and a ram on each altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Balaam said to Balak, “Stay here beside your burnt offering while I meet with God over there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh came to Balaam and told him, “Go back to Balak, and give him my message.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He came to Balak and found him standing beside his burnt offering with the princes of Moab. Balak asked him, “What did Yahweh say?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Balaam delivered this message:
“Stand up, Balak, and listen!
    Hear me, son of Zippor!
speaker: Narrator

text:
El is not like people. He tells no lies.
    He is not like humans. He doesn’t change his mind.
        When he says something, he does it.
        When he makes a promise, he keeps it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have received a command to bless.
    He has blessed, and I can’t change it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He doesn’t want any trouble for the descendants of Jacob.
    He sees no misfortune for the people of Israel.
Yahweh their Elohim is with them,
    praised as their king.
speaker: Narrator

text:
El who brought them out of Egypt
    has the strength of a wild bull.
speaker: Narrator

text:
No spell can curse the descendants of Jacob.
    No magic can harm the people of Israel.
Now it will be said of Jacob and Israel:
    ‘See what El has done!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Here is a nation that attacks like a lioness
    and is as ferocious as a lion.
        It doesn’t lie down until it eats its prey
            and drinks the blood of its victim.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balak said to Balaam, “If you won’t curse them, then at least don’t bless them!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam answered, “Didn’t I tell you that I must do whatever Yahweh says?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balak said to Balaam, “Come, let me take you to another place. Maybe Elohim wants you to curse them for me from there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Balak took Balaam to the top of Mount Peor, which overlooks Jeshimon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam said to Balak, “Build seven altars here, and prepare seven bulls and seven rams for me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balak did what Balaam told him, and he offered a bull and a ram on each altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Balaam saw that Yahweh wanted to bless Israel, he didn’t look for omens as he had done before. He turned toward the desert,
speaker: Narrator

text: looked up, and saw Israel’s camp grouped by tribes. The Ruach Elohim entered him,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and he delivered this message:
“This is the message of Balaam, son of Beor.
This is the message of the man whose eyesight is clear.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is the message of the one who hears the words of El,
    has a vision from Shadday,
        and falls into a trance with his eyes open:
speaker: Narrator

text:
How beautiful are your tents, Jacob,
    and the places where you live, Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your tents spread out like rivers,
    like gardens by a river,
        like aloes planted by Yahweh,
        like cedars by the water.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Water will flow from their buckets,
    and their crops will have plenty of water.
    Their king will be greater than Agag,
        and their kingdom will be considered the best.
speaker: Narrator

text:
El who brought them out of Egypt
    has the strength of a wild bull.
    He will devour nations that are his enemies,
        crush their bones,
            and pierce them with arrows.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His people lie down and rest like a lion.
    They are like a lioness. Who dares to disturb them?
    Those who bless you will be blessed!
    Those who curse you will be cursed!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balak became angry with Balaam. He clapped his hands and said, “I summoned you to curse my enemies, and now you have blessed them three times.
speaker: Narrator

text: Get out of here! Go home! I said I’d reward you richly, but Yahweh has made you lose your reward.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam answered Balak, “I told the messengers you sent me,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Even if Balak would give me his palace filled with silver and gold, I couldn’t disobey Yahweh’s command no matter how good or bad the request might seem to me. I must say only what Yahweh says.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Even though I’m going back to my people, I’ll give you some advice. I’ll tell you what these people will do to your people in the days to come.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Balaam delivered this message:
“This is the message of Balaam, son of Beor.
This is the message of the man whose eyesight is clear.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is the message of the one who hears the words of El,
    receives knowledge from Elyon,
        has a vision from Shadday,
            and falls into a trance with his eyes open:
speaker: Narrator

text:
I see someone who is not here now.
    I look at someone who is not nearby.
        A star will come from Jacob.
        A scepter will rise from Israel.
            He will crush the heads of the Moabites
                and destroy all the people of Sheth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Edom will be conquered,
    and Seir, his enemy, will be conquered.
        So Israel will become wealthy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will rule from Jacob
    and destroy whoever is left in their cities.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Balaam saw the Amalekites and delivered this message:
“Amalek was first among the nations,
    but in the end it will be destroyed.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then he saw the Kenites and delivered this message:
“You have a permanent place to live.
Your nest is built in a rock.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But it is destined to be burned, you descendants of Cain,
    when Assyria takes you as prisoners of war.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
He delivered this message:
“Oh no! Who will live when El decides to do this?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ships will come from the shores of Cyprus.
    They will conquer Assyria and Eber.
        But they, too, will be totally destroyed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Balaam got up and went back home, and Balak also went on his way.
speaker: Narrator

text: While Israel was staying at Shittim, the men began to have sex with Moabite women
speaker: Narrator

text: who invited the people to the sacrifices offered to their gods. The people ate the meat from the sacrifices and worshiped these gods.
speaker: Narrator

text: Since the Israelites joined in worshiping the god Baal of Peor, Yahweh became angry with Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh said to Moses, “Take all the leaders of the people, and execute them in broad daylight in Yahweh’s presence. This will turn Yahweh’s anger away from Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses said to the judges of Israel, “Each of you must kill the men who have joined in worshiping the god Baal of Peor.”
speaker: Narrator

text: One of the Israelite men brought a Midianite woman to his brothers. He did this right in front of Moses and the whole community of Israel while they were crying at the entrance to the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: Phinehas, son of Eleazar and grandson of the priest Aaron, saw this. So he left the assembly, took a spear in his hand,
speaker: Narrator

text: and went into the tent after the Israelite man. He drove the spear through the man and into the woman’s body. Because of this, the plague that the Israelites were experiencing stopped.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, 24,000 people died from that plague.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Yahweh said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Phinehas, son of Eleazar and grandson of the priest Aaron, turned my fury away from the Israelites. Since he stood up for me, I didn’t have to stand up for myself and destroy them.
speaker: Narrator

text: So tell Phinehas that I’m making a promise of peace to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: My promise is that he and his descendants will be priests permanently because he stood up for his Elohim and he made peace with the Lord for the Israelites.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The name of the Israelite man who was killed with the Midianite woman was Zimri, son of Salu. (Salu was the leader of a family from Simeon.)
speaker: Narrator

text: The name of the Midianite woman who was killed was Cozbi, daughter of Zur. (Zur was the head of a family from the Midianite tribes.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Treat the Midianites as your enemies, and kill them
speaker: Narrator

text: because they treated you as enemies. They plotted to trick you in the incident that took place at Peor. They used their sister Cozbi, daughter of a Midianite leader, who was killed on the day of the plague caused by the incident at Peor.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After the plague Yahweh said to Moses and Eleazar, son of the priest Aaron,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Take a census of the whole community of Israel by households. List those who are at least 20 years old and eligible for military duty.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses and the priest Eleazar spoke to the Israelites on the plains of Moab near the Jordan River across from Jericho. They said,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Take a census of those at least 20 years old, as Yahweh commanded Moses.”
These are the Israelites who came from Egypt:
speaker: Narrator

text: Reuben was Israel’s firstborn. The descendants of Reuben were the family of Hanoch, the family of Pallu,
speaker: Narrator

text: the family of Hezron, and the family of Carmi.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the families of Reuben. The total number of men was 43,730.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eliab was the son of Pallu,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Nemuel, Dathan, and Abiram were the sons of Eliab. (It was Dathan and Abiram, men chosen by the community, who defied Moses and Aaron’s authority. They joined Korah’s followers when they defied Yahweh’s authority.
speaker: Narrator

text: The ground opened up and swallowed them along with Korah. They and their followers died when the fire consumed the 250 men. This was a warning.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the descendants of Korah didn’t die.)
speaker: Narrator

text: The families descended from Simeon were the family of Nemuel, the family of Jamin, the family of Jakin,
speaker: Narrator

text: the family of Zerah, and the family of Shaul.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the families of Simeon. The total number of men was 22,200.
speaker: Narrator

text: The families descended from Gad were the family of Zephon, the family of Haggi, the family of Shuni,
speaker: Narrator

text: the family of Ozni, the family of Eri,
speaker: Narrator

text: the family of Arodi, and the family of Areli.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the families of Gad’s descendants. The total number of men was 40,500.
speaker: Narrator

text: Er and Onan were sons of Judah, but they died in Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: The families descended from Judah were the family of Shelah, the family of Perez, and the family of Zerah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Perez were the family of Hezron and the family of Hamul.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the families of Judah. The total number of men was 76,500.
speaker: Narrator

text: The families descended from Issachar were the family of Tola, the family of Puah,
speaker: Narrator

text: the family of Jashub, and the family of Shimron.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the families of Issachar. The total number of men was 64,300.
speaker: Narrator

text: The families descended from Zebulun were the family of Sered, the family of Elon, and the family of Jahleel.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the families of Zebulun. The total number of men was 60,500.
speaker: Narrator

text: The families descended from Joseph through Manasseh and Ephraim were
speaker: Narrator

text: (from Manasseh) the family of Machir (Machir was the father of Gilead) and the family of Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Gilead were the family of Iezer, the family of Helek,
speaker: Narrator

text: the family of Asriel, the family of Shechem,
speaker: Narrator

text: the family of Shemida, and the family of Hepher.
speaker: Narrator

text: (Zelophehad, son of Hepher, had no sons—only daughters. Their names were Mahlah, Noah, Hoglah, Milcah, and Tirzah.)
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the families of Manasseh. The total number of men was 52,700.
speaker: Narrator

text: The families descended from Ephraim were the family of Shuthelah, the family of Beker, and the family of Tahan.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Shuthelah were the family of Eran.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These were the families of Ephraim’s descendants. The total number of men was 32,500.
These were the families descended from Joseph.
speaker: Narrator

text: The families descended from Benjamin were the family of Bela, the family of Ashbel, the family of Ahiram,
speaker: Narrator

text: the family of Shupham, and the family of Hupham.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Bela (through Ard and Naaman) were the family of Ard and the family of Naaman.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the families descended from Benjamin. The total number of men was 45,600.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The family descended from Dan was the family of Shuham.
This was the family descended from Dan.
speaker: Narrator

text: The total number of men in all the family of Shuham was 64,400.
speaker: Narrator

text: The families descended from Asher were the family of Imnah, the family of Ishvi, and the family of Beriah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants Beriah were the family of Heber and the family of Malchiel.
speaker: Narrator

text: (Asher had a daughter named Serah.)
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the families of Asher’s descendants. The total number of men was 53,400.
speaker: Narrator

text: The families descended from Naphtali were the family of Jahzeel, the family of Guni,
speaker: Narrator

text: the family of Jezer, and the family of Shillem.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the families of Naphtali. The total number of men was 45,400.
speaker: Narrator

text: The total number of Israelite men was 601,730.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Yahweh said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “The land these people will possess must be divided using the list of names from the census.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give more land to larger tribes and less land to smaller ones. Use the totals from the census in giving land to each tribe.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the land must be divided by drawing lots. The tribes will receive their land based on the names of their ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whether the tribes are large or small, the land must be divided by drawing lots.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The families descended from Levi were listed as the family of Gershon, the family of Kohath, and the family of Merari.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These were the families of Levi: the Libnite family, the Hebronite family, the Mahlite family, the Mushite family, and the Korahite family.
Kohath was the ancestor of Amram.
speaker: Narrator

text: The name of Amram’s wife was Jochebed, a descendant of Levi, who was born in Egypt. She gave birth to Amram’s children: Aaron, Moses, and their sister Miriam.
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron was the father of Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Nadab and Abihu had died because they offered unauthorized fire in Yahweh’s presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: The total number of all the Levite males at least one month old was 23,000. They were not counted along with the other Israelites, because they were given no land of their own.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses and the priest Eleazar added up the total number of Israelites on the plains of Moab near the Jordan River across from Jericho.
speaker: Narrator

text: Among them there wasn’t a single one of the Israelites Moses and the priest Aaron had counted in the Desert of Sinai.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh had said, “They must all die in the desert.” The only ones left were Caleb (son of Jephunneh) and Joshua (son of Nun).
speaker: Narrator

text: The daughters of Zelophehad, son of Hepher, grandson of Gilead, descendant of Machir, whose father was Manasseh, belonged to the families of Manasseh, son of Joseph. Their names were Mahlah, Noah, Hoglah, Milcah, and Tirzah. They came
speaker: Narrator

text: to Moses and stood in front of him, the priest Eleazar, the leaders, and the whole community at the entrance to the tent of meeting. They said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Our father died in the desert. He was not a part of Korah’s followers who joined forces against Yahweh. He died for his own sin and left no sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: Why should our father’s name be allowed to die out in his family because he had no son? Give us property among our father’s relatives.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses brought their case to Yahweh,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Yahweh said to him,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Zelophehad’s daughters are right. You must give them property of their own among their father’s relatives. Turn their father’s property over to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell the Israelites: If a man dies and leaves no sons, turn his property over to his daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: If he has no daughters, give his property to his brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: If he has no brothers, give his property to his uncles on his father’s side of the family.
speaker: Narrator

text: If he has no uncles, give his property to the nearest relative in his family, and that relative will take possession of it. This will be a rule for the Israelites, as Yahweh commanded Moses.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh said to Moses, “Go up into the Abarim Mountains, and take a look at the land I will give the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: After you see it, you, too, will join your ancestors in death, as your brother Aaron did.
speaker: Narrator

text: You both rebelled against my command in the Desert of Zin. You didn’t show the people how holy I am when they were complaining at the oasis.” (This was the oasis of Meribah at Kadesh in the Desert of Zin.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to Yahweh,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Yahweh, you are the Elohim who gives the breath of life to everyone. Please appoint someone over the community
speaker: Narrator

text: who will lead them in and out of battle so that Yahweh’s community will not be like sheep without a shepherd.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Yahweh said to Moses, “Take Joshua, son of Nun, a man who has the Ruach, and place your hand on him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make him stand in front of the priest Eleazar and the whole community, and give him his instructions in their presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give him some of your authority so that the whole community of Israel will obey him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will stand in front of the priest Eleazar, who will use the Urim to make decisions in Yahweh’s presence. At his command Joshua and the whole community of Israel will go into battle. And at his command they will return.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses did as Yahweh commanded him. He took Joshua and made him stand in front of the priest Eleazar and the whole community.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses placed his hands on Joshua and gave him his instructions as Yahweh had told him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Give this command to the Israelites: Be sure to bring me my offerings at the right times. They are my food. They are offerings by fire, a soothing aroma.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the offerings by fire that you must bring to Yahweh. Every day you must bring as a daily burnt offering two one-year-old lambs that have no defects.
speaker: Narrator

text: Offer one in the morning and the other at dusk.
speaker: Narrator

text: With each of them also bring a grain offering of eight cups of flour mixed with one quart of virgin olive oil.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the daily burnt offering which was established on Mount Sinai. This offering is a soothing aroma, an offering by fire to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also bring a wine offering of one quart of wine for each lamb. Pour it out to Yahweh in a holy place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Offer the other lamb at dusk along with the same grain offering and wine offering as you brought in the morning. This is an offering by fire, a soothing aroma to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: “On the day of worship offer two one-year-old lambs that have no defects, a grain offering of 16 cups of flour mixed with olive oil, and the wine offering that goes with it.
speaker: Narrator

text: This burnt offering is for every day of worship in addition to the daily burnt offerings and the wine offerings that go with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “On the first of every month bring Yahweh a burnt offering of two young bulls, one ram, and seven one-year-old lambs that have no defects.
speaker: Narrator

text: With each bull there will be a grain offering of 24 cups of flour mixed with olive oil, with each ram a grain offering of 16 cups of flour mixed with olive oil,
speaker: Narrator

text: and with each one-year-old lamb a grain offering of 8 cups of flour mixed with olive oil. This is a burnt offering, a soothing aroma, an offering by fire to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: The wine offering that goes with each bull will be 2 quarts of wine, with each ram 1½ quarts of wine, and with each lamb 1 quart of wine. This will be the monthly burnt offering for every month of the year.
speaker: Narrator

text: In addition to the daily burnt offering with its wine offering, one male goat must be offered to Yahweh as an offering for sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The fourteenth day of the first month is Yahweh’s Passover.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fifteenth of this same month is a pilgrimage festival. For seven days you must eat only unleavened bread.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the first day there will be a holy assembly. Don’t do any regular work.
speaker: Narrator

text: Instead, bring Yahweh an offering by fire, a burnt offering of two young bulls, one ram, and seven one-year-old lambs, all of them without defects.
speaker: Narrator

text: Along with them bring grain offerings of flour mixed with olive oil. Bring 24 cups for each bull, 16 cups for each ram,
speaker: Narrator

text: and 8 cups for each of the seven lambs.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also bring one male goat as an offering for sin to make peace with the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Offer these in addition to the morning burnt offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bring all these offerings on each of the seven days. They are food. They are offerings by fire, a soothing aroma to Yahweh. They will be offered in addition to the daily burnt offering and the wine offering that goes with it.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the seventh day you must have a holy assembly. You must not do any regular work.
speaker: Narrator

text: “During the Festival of Weeks, you must have a holy assembly. On that day you must not do any regular work. Bring Yahweh your new grain offering, the first produce harvested from your fields.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bring a burnt offering as a soothing aroma to Yahweh—two young bulls, one ram, and seven one-year-old lambs.
speaker: Narrator

text: Along with them bring grain offerings of flour mixed with olive oil. Bring 24 cups for each bull, 16 cups for each ram,
speaker: Narrator

text: and 8 cups for each of the seven lambs.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also bring one male goat to make peace with the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Offer these animals that have no defects along with their wine offerings, in addition to the daily burnt offerings and their grain offerings.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord continued, “On the first day of the seventh month you must have a holy assembly. You must not do any regular work. It is a day for the trumpets to sound a fanfare.
speaker: Narrator

text: As a burnt offering, a soothing aroma to Yahweh, bring one young bull, one ram, and seven one-year-old lambs that have no defects.
speaker: Narrator

text: Along with them bring grain offerings of flour mixed with olive oil. Bring 24 cups for each bull, 16 cups for each ram,
speaker: Narrator

text: and 8 cups for each of the seven lambs.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also bring one male goat as an offering for sin to make peace with the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Offer these in addition to the monthly burnt offering with its grain offering, and the daily burnt offerings with their proper grain offerings and wine offerings. They are a soothing aroma, an offering by fire to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: “On the tenth day of the seventh month you must have a holy assembly. You must humble yourselves. You must not do any work.
speaker: Narrator

text: As a burnt offering, a soothing aroma, bring one young bull, one ram, and seven one-year-old lambs, all of them without defects.
speaker: Narrator

text: Along with them bring grain offerings of flour mixed with olive oil. Bring 24 cups for each bull, 16 cups for each ram,
speaker: Narrator

text: and 8 cups for each of the seven lambs.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also bring one male goat as an offering for sin (in addition to the other offering for sin to make peace with the Lord) and the daily burnt offerings with their grain offerings and wine offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: “On the fifteenth day of the seventh month you must have a holy assembly. You must not do any regular work. Instead, celebrate a festival to Yahweh for seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: As a burnt offering, an offering by fire, a soothing aroma to Yahweh, bring 13 young bulls, 2 rams, and 14 one-year-old lambs, all of them without defects.
speaker: Narrator

text: Along with them bring grain offerings of flour mixed with olive oil. Bring 24 cups for each of the 13 bulls, 16 cups for each of the 2 rams,
speaker: Narrator

text: and 8 cups for each of the 14 one-year-old lambs.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also bring one male goat as an offering for sin in addition to the daily burnt offerings with their grain offerings and wine offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: “On the second day bring 12 young bulls, 2 rams, and 14 one-year-old lambs that have no defects.
speaker: Narrator

text: Along with them bring the proper amount of grain offerings and wine offerings for each of the bulls, rams, and lambs.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also bring one male goat as an offering for sin in addition to the daily burnt offerings with their grain offerings and wine offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: “On the third day bring 11 bulls, 2 rams, and 14 one-year-old lambs that have no defects.
speaker: Narrator

text: Along with them bring the proper amount of grain offerings and wine offerings for each of the bulls, rams, and lambs.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also bring one male goat as an offering for sin in addition to the daily burnt offerings with their grain offerings and wine offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: “On the fourth day bring 10 bulls, 2 rams, and 14 one-year-old lambs that have no defects.
speaker: Narrator

text: Along with them bring the proper amount of grain offerings and wine offerings for each of the bulls, rams, and lambs.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also bring one male goat as an offering for sin in addition to the daily burnt offerings with their grain offerings and wine offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: “On the fifth day bring 9 bulls, 2 rams, and 14 one-year-old lambs that have no defects.
speaker: Narrator

text: Along with them bring the proper amount of grain offerings and wine offerings for each of the bulls, rams, and lambs.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also bring one male goat as an offering for sin in addition to the daily burnt offerings with their grain offerings and wine offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: “On the sixth day bring 8 bulls, 2 rams, and 14 one-year-old lambs that have no defects.
speaker: Narrator

text: Along with them bring the proper amount of grain offerings and wine offerings for each of the bulls, rams, and lambs.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also bring one male goat as an offering for sin in addition to the daily burnt offerings with their grain offerings and wine offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: “On the seventh day bring 7 bulls, 2 rams, and 14 one-year-old lambs that have no defects.
speaker: Narrator

text: Along with them bring the proper amount of grain offerings and wine offerings for each of the bulls, rams, and lambs.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also bring one male goat as an offering for sin in addition to the daily burnt offerings with their grain offerings and wine offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: “On the eighth day you must hold a religious assembly. You must not do any daily work.
speaker: Narrator

text: As a burnt offering, an offering by fire, a soothing aroma to Yahweh, bring one bull, one ram, and seven one-year-old lambs that have no defects.
speaker: Narrator

text: Along with them bring the proper amount of grain offerings and wine offerings for the bull, the ram, and the lambs.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also bring one male goat as an offering for sin in addition to the daily burnt offerings with their grain offerings and wine offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: “These are the offerings you must bring to Yahweh at your festivals. They are the offerings you must bring in addition to the offerings for anything you vowed to give to the Lord, your freewill offerings, your burnt offerings, your grain offerings, your wine offerings, and your fellowship offerings.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses told the Israelites everything Yahweh had commanded him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to the heads of the tribes of Israel, “This is what Yahweh has commanded about vows:
speaker: Narrator

text: If a man makes a vow to Yahweh that he will do something or swears an oath that he won’t do something, he must not break his word. He must do everything he said he would do.
speaker: Narrator

text: “A young girl, who still lives in her father’s house, might make a vow to Yahweh that she will do something or swear an oath that she won’t do something.
speaker: Narrator

text: If her father says nothing to her when he hears about it, her vow or oath must be kept.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if her father objects when he hears about it, her vow or oath doesn’t have to be kept. Yahweh will free her from this vow or oath because her father objected.
speaker: Narrator

text: “An unmarried woman might make a vow that she will do something or carelessly promise that she won’t do something. When she marries,
speaker: Narrator

text: her husband may hear about it but say nothing to her. Then her vow or oath must be kept.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if her husband objects when he hears about it, he can cancel the vow or promise she made. Yahweh will free her from this vow or promise.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But a widow or a divorced woman must keep her vow or her promise.
speaker: Narrator

text: “A married woman might make a vow that she will do something or swear an oath that she won’t do something.
speaker: Narrator

text: Her husband may hear about it but may say nothing and not object. Then her vow or oath must be kept.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if her husband cancels it when he hears about it, nothing she said in her vow or oath has to be kept. Her husband has canceled it, and Yahweh will free her from this vow or oath.
speaker: Narrator

text: “A husband decides whether or not his wife has to keep any vow to do something or any oath to do without something.
speaker: Narrator

text: If he says nothing to her about it day after day, this means he’s decided that she must keep her vow or oath. She must keep it because he said nothing to her when he heard about it.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if he cancels it later, he will suffer the consequences.”
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the laws Yahweh gave Moses for husbands and wives, and for fathers with young daughters still living at home.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Get even with the Midianites for what they did to the Israelites. After that you will join your ancestors in death.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to the people, “Some of your men must get ready to go to war against the Midianites. Yahweh will use them to get even with Midian.
speaker: Narrator

text: Send 1,000 men from each of the tribes of Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So 1,000 men from each tribe were supplied from the divisions of Israel—12,000 men ready for war.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses sent them off to war, 1,000 men from each tribe along with Phinehas, son of the priest Eleazar. Phinehas took with him the holy articles and the trumpets for the fanfare.
speaker: Narrator

text: They went to war against Midian, as Yahweh commanded Moses, and killed every man.
speaker: Narrator

text: Among those killed were the five kings of Midian—Evi, Rekem, Zur, Hur, and Reba. They also killed Balaam, son of Beor, in battle.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites took the Midianite women and children as prisoners of war. They also took all their animals, their livestock, and their valuables as loot.
speaker: Narrator

text: They burned all the cities where the Midianites lived and all their settlements.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they took everything as loot, including all the people and animals,
speaker: Narrator

text: and brought the prisoners of war, the loot, and everything to Moses, the priest Eleazar, and the community of Israel at the camp on the plains of Moab near the Jordan River across from Jericho.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses, the priest Eleazar, and all the leaders of the community went outside the camp to meet them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses was angry with the officers of the army, the commanders of the companies and battalions, who were returning from battle.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Why did you let all the women live?” he asked them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Remember, they were the ones who followed Balaam’s advice and caused the Israelites to be unfaithful to Yahweh in the incident that took place at Peor. Yahweh’s community experienced a plague at that time.
speaker: Narrator

text: So kill all the Midianite boys and every Midianite woman who has gone to bed with a man.
speaker: Narrator

text: But save for yourselves every girl who has never gone to bed with a man.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Everyone who killed a person or touched a dead body must stay outside the camp seven days. You and your prisoners of war must use the ritual water on the third and seventh days in order to take away your sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do the same for all the clothes and everything made of leather, goats’ hair, or wood.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the priest Eleazar said to the soldiers who had gone into battle, “This is what Yahweh’s teachings told Moses to do:
speaker: Narrator

text: Any gold, silver, bronze, iron, tin, or lead—
speaker: Narrator

text: anything that won’t burn—must be put through fire in order to make it clean. Then it must also be put through the ritual water in order to take away its sin. Whatever might burn must only be put through the ritual water.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the seventh day wash your clothes, and you will be clean. Then you may come into the camp.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “You, the priest Eleazar, and the heads of the families of the community need to count all the loot, including the people and animals you captured.
speaker: Narrator

text: Divide the loot between the soldiers who served in the war and the rest of the community.
speaker: Narrator

text: Collect a tax for Yahweh. From the soldiers who served in the war collect one out of every 500 things. This includes people, cattle, donkeys, sheep, and goats.
speaker: Narrator

text: Collect all these things from the soldiers’ half of the loot, and give them to the priest Eleazar as a contribution to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the Israelites’ half of the loot, collect one out of every 50 things. This includes people, cattle, donkeys, sheep, goats, and every other kind of animal. Give them to the Levites who are in charge of the work done at Yahweh’s tent.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses and the priest Eleazar did as Yahweh commanded Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the loot that was left from everything that the troops took: 675,000 sheep and goats,
speaker: Narrator

text: 72,000 cattle,
speaker: Narrator

text: 61,000 donkeys, and
speaker: Narrator

text: 32,000 women who had never gone to bed with a man.
speaker: Narrator

text: Half of it went to the soldiers who served in the war. Of the 337,500 sheep and goats they received,
speaker: Narrator

text: 675 went to Yahweh as taxes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Of the 36,000 cattle they received, 72 went to Yahweh as taxes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Of the 30,500 donkeys they received, 61 went to Yahweh as taxes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Of the 16,000 people they received, 32 went to Yahweh as taxes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses gave Yahweh’s taxes to the priest Eleazar, as Yahweh had commanded him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses took the Israelites’ half of the loot from the soldiers.
speaker: Narrator

text: The community received 337,500 sheep and goats,
speaker: Narrator

text: 36,000 cattle,
speaker: Narrator

text: 30,500 donkeys,
speaker: Narrator

text: and 16,000 people.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the Israelites’ half Moses collected one out of every 50 things, including people and animals, as Yahweh commanded him. Then he gave all this to the Levites who were in charge of the work done at Yahweh’s tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the officers from the military divisions, the commanders of the companies and battalions of men, came to Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to him, “Sir, we have counted all the soldiers under our command, and not one of them is missing.
speaker: Narrator

text: So we have brought as gifts to Yahweh the gold jewelry that each of us found—arm bands, bracelets, signet rings, earrings, and pendants. We offer them to make peace with the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses and the priest Eleazar took all the hand-crafted gold articles from them.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the gold contributed to Yahweh by the commanders weighed about 420 pounds.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each soldier kept his own loot.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses and the priest Eleazar took the gold from the commanders and brought it into Yahweh’s presence at the tent of meeting as a reminder to the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: The tribes of Reuben and Gad had a large number of livestock. They saw that the regions of Jazer and Gilead were a good place for livestock.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they came to Moses, the priest Eleazar, and the leaders of the community, and said to them,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Ataroth, Dibon, Jazer, Nimrah, Heshbon, Elealeh, Sebam, Nebo, and Beon,
speaker: Narrator

text: the land that Yahweh won for the community of Israel, is a good place for livestock. Gentlemen, we have livestock.
speaker: Narrator

text: Please give us this land as our property. Don’t make us cross the Jordan River.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses asked the tribes of Gad and Reuben, “Are you going to stay here while the rest of the Israelites go to war?
speaker: Narrator

text: That might discourage them from entering the land Yahweh has given them.
speaker: Narrator

text: That’s what your ancestors did when I sent them from Kadesh Barnea to take a look at the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: They went as far as the Eshcol Valley and saw the land. But then they discouraged the rest of the Israelites from entering the land that Yahweh had given them.
speaker: Narrator

text: That day Yahweh became angry and swore this oath,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘None of the people 20 years old or older, who came from Egypt, will see the land I promised Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob with an oath. This is because they didn’t wholeheartedly follow me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Only Caleb (son of Jephunneh the Kenizzite) and Joshua (son of Nun) will get to see the land. This is because they wholeheartedly followed Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Since Yahweh was angry with the Israelites, he made them wander in the desert for 40 years until the whole generation of those who had done evil in Yahweh’s presence was gone.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You’re just like your parents! You’re a bunch of sinners trying to make Yahweh angry with Israel again.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you turn away from him, he will abandon all these people in the desert. You would be responsible for their destruction.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the tribes of Gad and Reuben came up to Moses and said, “Allow us to build stone fences for our livestock and cities for our families here.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then we’ll be ready to march in battle formation ahead of the other Israelites until we have brought them to their land. Meanwhile our families will live in walled cities, safe from the other people who live here.
speaker: Narrator

text: We will not return to our homes until every Israelite has received his own land.
speaker: Narrator

text: We won’t take possession of any land on the other side of the Jordan River, to the west and beyond. We already have our land here, east of the Jordan.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses answered, “Do what you have said. In Yahweh’s presence have all your armed men get ready for battle.
speaker: Narrator

text: Have them cross the Jordan, and fight until Yahweh forces out his enemies
speaker: Narrator

text: and the land is conquered. Then you may come back. You will have fulfilled your military duty to Yahweh and Israel. This land will be your own property in Yahweh’s presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If you don’t do all these things, you will be sinning against Yahweh. You can be sure that you will be punished for your sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Build cities for your families and stone fences for your flocks, but do what you have promised.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the tribes of Gad and Reuben said to Moses, “Sir, we will do as you command.
speaker: Narrator

text: Our children, our wives, our livestock, and all our other animals will stay here in the cities of Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: But in Yahweh’s presence we will all get ready for battle and go with you, as you have said.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses gave orders about them to the priest Eleazar, Joshua (son of Nun), and the family heads of the tribes of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses told them, “If the tribes of Gad and Reuben get ready for battle in Yahweh’s presence and cross the Jordan River with you and you conquer the land, give them Gilead as their own property.
speaker: Narrator

text: If they don’t get ready for battle and go with you, the land they will take possession of must be in Canaan with yours.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The tribes of Gad and Reuben answered, “Sir, we will do as Yahweh has said.
speaker: Narrator

text: We will enter Canaan as armed troops in Yahweh’s presence, but the land we will take possession of is here, east of the Jordan.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses gave the tribes of Gad, Reuben, and half of the tribe of Manasseh, son of Joseph, the kingdoms of King Sihon of the Amorites and King Og of Bashan—the whole land with its cities and its surrounding territory.
speaker: Narrator

text: The tribe of Gad rebuilt the cities of Dibon, Ataroth, Aroer,
speaker: Narrator

text: Atroth Shophan, Jazer, Jogbehah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Beth Nimrah, and Beth Haran as walled cities. They also built stone fences for their flocks.
speaker: Narrator

text: The tribe of Reuben rebuilt the cities of Heshbon, Elealeh, Kiriathaim,
speaker: Narrator

text: Nebo, Baal Meon (whose names were changed), and Sibmah. These are the names they gave the cities they rebuilt.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Machir, son of Manasseh, went to Gilead, captured it, and forced out the Amorites who were there.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses gave Gilead to the people of Machir (the descendants of Manasseh), and they lived there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jair, a descendant of Manasseh, captured the settlements in Gilead. He called them Havvoth Jair [Settlements of Jair].
speaker: Narrator

text: Nobah captured Kenath and its villages. He named it Nobah after himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is a list of all the places where the Israelites set up camp after they left Egypt in organized groups under the leadership of Moses and Aaron.
speaker: Narrator

text: At Yahweh’s command Moses wrote down the places where they went as they traveled. This is the list:
speaker: Narrator

text: They moved from Rameses on the fifteenth day of the first month, the day after the Passover. The Israelites boldly left in full view of all the Egyptians.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Egyptians were burying all their firstborn sons, whom Yahweh had killed in a mighty act of judgment on their gods.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites moved from Rameses and set up camp at Succoth.
speaker: Narrator

text: They moved from Succoth and set up camp at Etham, on the edge of the desert.
speaker: Narrator

text: They moved from Etham and turned back to Pi Hahiroth, east of Baal Zephon, and set up camp near Migdol.
speaker: Narrator
